This is one of my favorite food festivals in NYC. I actually went yesterday with some friends.
Reasonable price, offered free giveaways/samples, great food and drinks, and fun games for kids. If you want to get some freebies you should definitely visit between 52nd St-57th Street.
They usually gave out free snacks, drinks and candies. For this year, one of the most unique food vendors I have seen so far was Hyonie's. They sell potadogs (corndogs battered with fries and topped with different sauces). It was delicious and crispy. One of the popular one was the paella vendor featured a big wok filled with seafood paella. I believed it cost about $10.
I recognized several vendors that participated last year such as Vivi buble tea, empanada mama, otto's tacos, arepas, etc. For Vivi bubble tea, I have no idea why they sell their regular bubble tea for $5. Vivi's booth is right in front of their actual store and their regular price is $3.50. People are not blind lol

Not what it used to be. I live in the neighborhood and just went down to get a couple of Sausage & Peppers Subs... on the corner of 9th & 43 St... $20 each. Ridiculous and not even room temp. Not too long ago they were $10... now $20 for a lousy sub. Not worth it... and not good quality. This particular stand doesn't show any prices, so you have no idea what the cost is until you step up to pay. 2 subs... $40! Never again. They weren't even warm... let alone hot. Shame on them and the festival itself. Obviously not catering to the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood.

Come hungry and prepare to be tempted. We randomly came across the festival but ended up going on both Saturday and Sunday.

Plenty of local restaurants are offering up food, the SPAM truck had a line that never seemed to go away, and there was free gelato (or ice cream?) cups being given away from a vendor I could never seem to find.

Drinks are everywhere, and there's really nothing better than walking up and down the middle of 9th avenue with an ice cold beer in your hand, be it the $3 thai beer or the $8 coney island pilsner.

There was a lot of food - not as much from the local restaurants, but plenty to choose from. There was a gyro every 6 feet, plenty of sausages and peppers, plates of paella the size of the moon, and plenty of meats on sticks, including gigantic turkey legs.

Oh, and fried oreos -- which I avoided because Dough was there, and I was suddenly feeling that a midday mocha donut would pair really well with my beer. Spoiler: yes, it did.

In any case, there are other vendors (plants, crafts, soap, clothes, art, etc.) to look at, plenty of music, and when all else fails -- some really interesting people watching. If you missed it this year, definitely add it to your calendar for 2018.

Rude Italian sausage food stall worker cursed me out.

The festival was not as international as the name implied: all of the food stalls were standard street food fare. Mall food court offerings are just as diverse as this festival.

Also, I cannot believe how rude an Italian Sausage food stall worker was to me. I paid for my food and asked to have it cut in fourths. He thought I was asking for four more orders, I said no and asked again. When it was clear that he could not hear me due to background drilling, I just politely indicated to have my order just as it was.

Keep in mind: I was making his job easier by not pursuing my ask and taking my food just as it is. The result: the food worker just started cursing me out. What? If he has a problem hearing customers over background noise, he should not be taking this out on customers who are clearly not taking it out on him.

I posted the stall picture I took from a distance. Please steer clear of people from the Italian Sausage food stall because its employees have anger management issues.

I work in the area and during my many walks from 59th Street to the 33rd Street PATH station via 9th Avenue, I've marveled at all the happy hours and specials that the restaurants on this block have to offer. Having only ventured in a select few of my regular spots, I was excited about this festival, knowing it would feature not only international foods throughout NYC, but 9th Avenue as well.

This 2012 weekend was a busy one!!!
In this neighborhood alone, there was a dance parade on Broadway and a tattoo convention on 52nd. You know I had to hit up the tattoo convention!

With the little bit of time I had to enjoy this festival, I tried to take in as much as I could. I had a great time, don't get me wrong, but I feel like I walked away with some disappointments:
** It wasn't as "international" as its namesake had me thinking it would be (the FTR failed to give it its full name:  9th Avenue International Food festival).
** I felt most of the food was typical festival fare and I would've been able to find them anywhere.
** I didn't feel 9th Avenue was featured at all. Most 9th Avenue businesses may have put out some tents, tables, and chairs out front, but you're ordering from the staff and menu inside. I guess I was expecting something other than just added outdoor seating.

I did have a bit of excitement. I was eyeing the alligator sausage stand at the Hoboken Arts and Music Festival, but didn't get around to it. I was on a mission to find it out here...and I did. That was exciting, the "finding" part. The actual sausage was anticlimactic. It tasted like any other sausage. Having never had alligator before, I didn't know what subtleties to look for. They could have given me a regular ol' pork sausage and I wouldn't have known.

Having no other years to compare this year's festival to, I can't say if things are getting better or worse. It may not have met my expectations, but I still had a good time and I would indeed do it again next year.

Today is 5/19 Sunday, this festival also combined with Japan food town festival, located on 9th Avenue and 56th Street - 57th Street, total around 10 Japanese style shops including reman, desert and usual popular Japanese snacks. 6 of the shop owners travel from Japan to US for this food street fair and was very worth to visit and try. Average noodle price is around $10 and snacks around $8-11 per order. Food portion was big, but was acceptable. Just happened that there is a regular 9th Avenue Street fair going on at the same time, also on 9th Avenue, but from 55th Street to all the way down to 43th Street, it's called international food street fair, and over 100 shops there, including Jamaican food, Argentina food, German sausage, jumbo size turkey leg, and of cos... lots of them actually sell liquor or beers by their food stand, but you can't walk around with alcohol in NYC and every block there is a NYPD, meaning you will have to consume all liquor onsite or before you leave that stand. It was quite a nice street fair, everything wasn't pricy, average around $8-15 per order for food, and $3-5 per order for appetizer or snacks such as corn or cookies. And around $5-10 per order for liquor. For parking, it is horrible and so hard to find a spot, I would recommend everyone to park far away and walk back to this fair, otherwise it will take you even longer time to leave and move car out. One thing to mention is their grilled corn, it's the most cheapest grill corn I have ever bought on street, for $3 each. And everyone should try "5 Napkins burger" stand, since there restaurant has high rating and always packed, it's nice to try out their food stand and try all flavors easy and quick. Overall, I give this event a super A+ rating and recommend all to try out and bring kids too. (There is a block that has kids playground or temporary inflatable playground). Oh, by the way, lots of vendors are giving out "whole box" of free beverages or food or candy, including McDonald's and TUMs. And maybe that's why I wrote so much about this and love this event...

I don't usually like these kind of street fairs but I stumbled into this one and I think I'd go again.It has some interesting trinkets on sale at some booths and some good food stands.I didn't eat ,I'd already had lunch but unlike your usual fairs with disgusting looking Italian sausage and fried dough stuff(fried usually in left over industrial sludge) there were items I actually wanted to try.I was fascinated by the giant turkey legs ! There was a roast suckling pig  turning in all its glory.Ecuadorian food stands , German food and Polish food.And you could get beer!I did try Bronx Pale Ale- and it's good.It beat going up there for it. I also had an IPA from Coney Island Brewing.A lot of the restaurants participate in this and they seem pretty open about letting you use the bathroom.

Although the internationality was really awesome, the quality and quantity of food for the high prices was not worth it. There was definitely a really nice selection of foods from different countries being represented though! The street was pretty dirty and there weren't many trash cans scattered about, and the streets weren't closed to traffic so everyone had to wait for the streetlights to cross the street. Cool place to check out but I definitely don't suggest eating here. I saw some businesses I've been to and they definitely raised their prices at this food festival.

Food is the international unspoken language that unites all cultures.  We live to eat, period.

Foodie is what comforts me in my darkest days as 2014, I stroll New York's Ninth Avenue to see what edible gems lie.  Two Empanadas at $5.00, yes!  There were many local restaurants that partake this event.  Clothing and kiddie games are available but not to my interest.  Yes, family friendly.  This event is recurring every year, so if you missed this year you still have the next to look forward to in the month of May.

More like a 3.5 star street festival. Like another reviewer mentioned, they pretty much clone each block and not many actual Hell's Kitchen restaurants are represented.

However, all the food I tried was tasty and pretty reasonably priced. Also, there were a few food companies giving away samples of products. For example, Post cereal was there giving away coupons and samples of a few of their cereals.

While there I tried Arepa...I think that was the name. It's basically a lightly sweet corn cake sandwich with mozzarella inside. Very tasty. I had some chocolate covered strawberries, a Jell-O shot, really good chocolate caramel popcorn, fresh lemonade and a wonderful empanada from Empanada Mama. It was mozzarella with guava...sooo good!!!

Overall this is definitely a fun place to walk around for an hour or two. Tasty eats, some live music, free samples...all in all a fun way to spend some of your day! One tip is to come early when it's cooler out and not as crowded.

Go in with a strategy ... don't eat a bunch of starchy foods and anything with a bunch of rice because you will get full faster. I've been going for 10 years now and I recommend polish & German sausages, takoyaki, arepas, that one Greek restaurant with a stand, and anything with a pig roasting!

It was listed as starting at 38th on their official website...it started at 42nd.

Half the vendors I expected to see didn't bother setting  up. In fact a few had empty spots in front of their place, which settled that theory. I can imagine the cries of "oh it's the economy, setting a booth up isn't feasible" - yeah selling samples of your food at lower prices, which generates business as people now know how good your food is, isn't practical. Give me a break. I can't imagine that the sham-wow tent or tea & spice fellas make a killing, but there they are at every street fair this summer.

Yes, it looked like every other street fair going on weekly around here. But then again, it was fitting. The hype and pride of a neighborhood has just been homogenized into the generic.  Will defnitely not put aside time for it.

Reviewing the 2010 iteration of the "INTERNATIONAL* FOOD FESTIVAL":

I'd like to start by mentioning that I just love how tourists prance (if only they were so graceful) around Midtown content and naive, thinking "Oh, this is New York, how enchanting".

Regardless, the food was mediocre at best, and the removal of the moniker "International" from the listing is telling, but here's a cursory rundown for those who curr:

Louie G spelled "Canoli" wrong, but made it just right
Brickyard Gastropub stationed outside their place, and took forever to deliver decent Crabcake Sliders & Fig Mascarpone In Phyllo
Hallo Berlin's Potato Pancake was served up in front of their store and illustrated some awful service
Rice & Beans folks were attentive but disorganized, and their codfish croquette was meh
Come and get it BBQ was hectic and their corn on the cob with lime butter was uncooked corn with a tub of hard butter?
Sadly, the standard street fair vendors were the best part, and I enjoyed my traditional candy Apple over things like Rachel's Sliders' Lobster Slider & Gazpacho Pasta Salad, though they topped the other wares here.

Stretching from 42nd up to 57th, this street fair is a great way to spend a few hours of the weekend. Beyond food vendors ranging from BBQ to Indian to Japanese, there were carnival games and free product giveaways. My favorite spots were Sam's Fried Ice Cream, the Meatball Shop, and Daisy Mae's BBQ. There were a few people giving out samples of the most delicious Caribbean rum cake I have ever tasted! It was pretty crowded on Sunday, but I expected that given the beautiful weather and abundant sunshine.

I look forward to the Ninth Avenue Food Festival every year.  It is has the typical street fair stands.  But local restaurants also have stands where you can sample their popular dishes.  There is a wide variety of food to choose from.

I look forward to Dalton's pork sandwiches.  The pork is from a pig on a spit that they cook right at their stand.  Juicy and succulent!!

Southern Hospitality opened a restaurant in HK this past year and have a stand for the first time.  Their ribs are to die for!  I am definitely going there for dinner soon!

The "9th Avenue International Food Festival" is full of food, fun, festivities, and freakin' delightful debauchery. More on that later.

On a semi recent business trip to New York, I sat in my hotel room frustrated that Southwest Airlines (Chicago) had misplaced my luggage the night before, and that I would be without my belongings until later that afternoon. So I'd have to live without my sensitive skin exfoliating face wash, clinical protection Secret deodorant, and expensive hair product. For the record, I am not a woman.

Going crazy in my hotel room, I opted to go for a walk around Hell's Kitchen with slightly disheveled hair, a 5 o'clock shadow, and the same clothes I had worn the day before. Essentially, it's sort like a "walk of shame" minus the fatigue, head splitting hangover, and general embarrassment of going home with a wildebeest.

Anyway, I am really glad I got out of my room. I happened to stumble across the "9th Avenue International Food Festival" and this was an awesome way to spend a few hours. It's full of little booths that sell a diverse array of food, snacks, drinks, and other items such as t-shirts, souvenirs, crafts, and fake designer handbags.

Since I was starving, I was able to try the cuisine a full plate of tasty Indian/Pakistani food from Bombay Express for $5. I had some sugary sweet lemonade from another stand for a $1.50. And for dessert, I enjoyed a couple of orgasmic explosions in my mouth, or in other words, two fried Oreo cookies for $1. All in all, one of the cheaper meals I have ever enjoyed in New York (that didn't come from McDonald's or a food cart).

However, the best part of the festival was diversity of the people, culture, languages, and the vibrant energy that can only come from New York. And one area of the festival in particular, captured New York City and the "9th Avenue International Food Festival" for me.

Here's the scene: There were some Latinos, ranging from Puerto Rican to Dominican, on the sidewalk listening to some salsa music. One Latino guy starts playing a bongo drum of sorts. And then another Latino guy starts shaking his maracas. Next thing you know, you have a group people dancing on the sidewalk and in the streets.

The energy and the vibe was infectious. A darker Latino guy with dyed blond hair, a tye dye cut off t-shirt, and some (super short) white shorts starts really showing off his salsa moves. All of a sudden, a larger man comes along, dressed in a long dress with a blond wig and a parrot on his shoulder and small spray painted dog at his feet and he proceeds to shows off his dance moves. As they start to dance together, the crowd begins to cheer for both of them.

Out of nowhere, a small older Latino man dressed in a little tan suit straight of "Mad Men" starts to get down with his salsa moves. At this point, the crowd erupts into a frenzy. And I don't blame them. This guy was around 80 years old, but could out dance anyone on the block. He was the coolest old man I had come across in a long time.

And in the end, this is the most fun I have had at a festival in a long time.

I'm definitely a fan.

Thought I should writean update on day 2. The weather has been great so the streets are packed. The food as always....hmmmm. I have already eaten in the restaurants of 9th Ave represented. Their tastings were decent but in general their food IN the restaurants is much better.
While billed as an "International Food Festival," there are more cheep jewelry booths, hats, wallets and belt booths, and even NYTime booths. Wouldn't it be nice to have just a food fare?

Welcome to NY Street Fare season. Same stuff everywhere blocking off traffic. Hurray!

It was fun! Not far from the hotel we stayed at (8th ave). So many different food options. I'm glad we got there early because by the time we left, lines were getting really long and it was getting crowded but the weather was beautiful. Nice booths everyone we approached was friendly and the food was excellent. I tried some Empanadas from Freakin Rican so so good. I had to stop myself from purchasing another. Had sliders from 5 Napkin Restaurant. Super good. The burger had caramelized onions and garlic aioli. Perfect portion. I had grilled corn on the cob and some watermelon that was very sweet! Loved it. We got lemonade from a booth that was selling it for just $1-$2. We want to come back this time next year to go again
Im hoping for delicious pizza, meatball, wings,jerk flavoring, mac cheese, ice cream, im hoping i find a vendor with ginger beer....hmmmm excited lol true foodie here

This was my first time going to a food festival, and it was definitely a good time. I had the onion rings/loaf thing that everyone seemed to be carrying around ($7), which I only got to eat some of and then had to chuck it because I wanted something else, which was mac n cheese ($4), from one of the Caribbean vendors which not the best, actually, not even good. Or hot. Or had taste.
I was it all down with a VERY sweet bucket of lemonade ($3) and had strawberry cheesecake ($4) which was pretty good- kinda mushy then what I'm used to, but still good nonetheless. It was a pretty huge fair, and next time I'm going to make sure I smoke five blunts before I go here because I know there is a lot more that I need to pack in.
I also got to see Chris March from Project Runway who I think is an amazing designer and he was eating the same greasy crap I was! I love it!

This is a huge fair/festival, even by NYC standards! It spans like 20 city blocks! Most of the food is a repetition of what you'll find on the street before but there are ones that are unique and stand out. Look for the stand around 51st street selling Jamaican food. The jerk chicken, oxtail and plaintains are delicious! I would go back just for that again.

I've gotten into a habit of hunting down food fairs just to look for my favorite food vendor Kettlecorn NYC, how they manage to keep their popcorn, fresh and crisp for a week is beyond me, but it's all that and more. The flavors, the crunchiness that never seems to go away. Amazing!

I love it. It was a lots of fun while walking in 9th avenue. Only think I didn't like is they don't care about hygiene. Water is limited and they don't wash their hands during the festival. Maybe they need to buy a hand sanitizer at least lol

It's a street fair.  You know going in that you're going to get ripped off by just about everyone.  Every block you walk you will see people selling sausage and pepper heroes, corn dogs, "authentic" Mexican cuisine, several types of deep fried goodness or nastiness (depending), and can probably get away with a little open container violation if you're slick about it.  
I spent $4 bucks on a chicken empanada that was pretty underwhelming (can a brother get some pico de gallo or somethin'?!?!), dropped $5 on some fried oreos (my stomach is still angry at me for that one) and dropped another $5 on a cold, tasteless pulled pork sandwich from Dalton's.  I shouldn't feel too bad though...they also tricked Michael Boatman and Steven Weber, on line in front of me, into buying their sandwiches (someone please find these guys some work!).  The best thing I spent my money on was a Summer Ale.  

I also saw a church bake sale of sorts around 44th Street with some tiramisu and cheesecake, unrefrigerated and just hanging out in the danger zone...that is a BIG no-no.

My wife and I had gagged down a poor breakfast at Euro cafe earlier in the day and had finished the Sunday Times. We were bored and it was raining so we left our hotel, walked a couple blocks and checked this festival out. It was 15 blocks of mostly the same crap you'd see at any county fair but the food selections were pretty good. We tried a couple things and all in all had a good time people watching and observing.

I guess it only happens once a year but I'm glad we were able to enjoy it. I liked the whole pig on the spit the best.

A NYC classic.  Who cares that there are several smoothie stands, shish kebab carts , etc. There are still several booths with fantastic and different types of food which I would not normally eat. I have been coming for almost forty years and regret the few times that I have been out of town and unable to make it.
We have been going for the past 5 years! sometimes finding a new items. A great trip to plan 15 blocks of food and drinks!

Pretty nice street festival. Some of the same booths repeated every few blocks like sweet corn with mozzarella and crepes, but some unique places too. Most dishes are around $5, ok price given the size. Quality of the food is decent, not amazing but the atmosphere is worth going for. Lots of people, enticing aromas, music, and some good free samples too. Happens every May, worth checking out, especially if you have kids

This would have been so much better if there had been more of the local restaurants.  As a fan of 9th Ave dining, I was hoping to see most of the restaurants represented.  Unfortunately this was not the case.  Not only did the majority NOT have booths, it was your typical street fair cuisine.  Picture endless funnel cake stands, sausage and pepper stands, etc.  Bah, Meh, whoopee...

Same vendors you generally see around the city with a couple of actual restaurants from Hells Kitchen representing. But overall, a really fun street fair. There are free samples (not too many) and incredibly cheap eats.

Word of advice to my cheap-friends: Go around closing time - vendors lower prices and are desperate to get rid of food. A friend of mine actually got a free sandwich and watermelon!

I felt the "international" was misleading. It's more like a large carnival minus the rides and also what the hell was up with the Shamwow booths? That really ruined the idea of "food festival" for me. The Colombian booths were really tasty and if you love deep fried anything there's definitely plenty of that here. The deep fried Oreos are one of the most decadent things I've ever eaten.

There was definitely a lot of food on every single block, but some food and smoothie stands could be seen every block.  Overall I'd have to say, be prepared to come with quite a bit of money as some of the stuff can get a tad bit expensive.
For example: lamb gyros were $9, and Takoyaki (6 pieces) were $8.  But it's an interesting place to come if you want to see some different kinds of food.  I was just a little bit disappointed to see not as many restaurants as I thought had stands.    
At the very end of the food festival there were various cultural performances and that was pretty awesome.

Visited the 9th ave food fest in May 2014. There were tons of people and plenty of food to be had! However, didnt feel like there was much of a variety. It looked like they cloned each block. There was the roasted corn, fresh lemondae, corn dogs, sausage...etc stands on every block over & over. I was looking for more Hels Kitchen restaurants showcased. This is a fest i recommend stopping by if you're in the area but i wouldnt go out of my way to attend.

It seems to me this festival turns more into a flea market/ carnival every year. Years ago, I remember pig heads on a grill and seafood and many ethnic foods. Not anymore. But that stretch of 9th avenue has many great food establishments that are  worth a trip! Just going to Poseidon bakery makes it all worth while :) And the soy milk soft serve at Kyotofu :)

I was expecting a lot more than the completely generic street fair vendors.  Granted, there were a few 9th Ave. restaurants with stands, but the majority was the same junk you can find anywhere, so I was a little disappointed.  Still, I had some good food that was priced pretty reasonably.  And there were some good vendors (Yankee tee-shirts for $10 and big spice containers for a few bucks) and good free sample (kettle corn and Lipton iced teas).  I'd also definitely recommend coming here if you have kids--there were puppet shows, bouncy rides, and more.  I just wish more restaurants in the area participated!

best chicken, rice and salad...5 bucks...deliciously fresh....always tastes a bit different..clean...owner is so friendly...i have this every day for lunch and dont get tired....they have lamb, eggplant, falafel....run to this cart!

The guy is a complete rip off and fraud. Go somewhere else. Many other halal carts around.
Charged $20 for chicken over rice.

Came here at night on a Thursday and ordered lamb over rice. He told me the price was $9. Came back again and asked for the price first, and it was miraculously $7.

This halal cart scams you, owner is extremely disrespectful, and the meat is not fresh.

DON'T GO HERE!!!!!

For super inexpensive pizza this place rocks! It's good and cheap and open late. They have tasty garlic knots too. Variety of slices you can grab and go until about 2 am most days. We grab pizza here almost every visit!

Not much seating so be prepared to stand or take it to go.

This place was packed as I was walking by and I saw some people devouring their slices right on the sidewalk. First time here in NY and this was a really cool first NY pizza experience.

Pizza was delicious and it smelled sooooo good so naturally I could not wait to eat it and I burned the roof of my mouth hahaha but let I'll tell you what! It was worth it!

Great place to get a quick bite and on a perfect corner where you can just stand and people watch :)

They have limited seating and a couple tables to stand and eat by.

Enjoy!

Amazing pizza.
During my stay in NY returned to there countless times.
Highly recommended.

FOOD - better than Joe's by far. very fresh and didn't taste like it was days old. good ratio of toppings to cheese and breading.

PRICE - like $4 for a slice I think

If you are looking for quick, cheap and decent pizza, this is the place. Is it the best slice I've had in NY? No. But it got the job done to keep me content until the five hours for dinner.
Staff is expedient. They may not be friendly but that's because of the volume and speed at which they operate not to mention the occasional person they have to ask to leave the premises.
I know there are cheaper places you can go but you are paying some of the cost with the time spent in those lines.

The pizza was delicious - cheap, big, oven styled pizza. I had the margarita and the ricotta white pizza and both were delicious and fresh. The atmosphere was a bit sketchy though, lots of loitering around it and it's a bit smelly on the outskirts. The food is great, the shop is small and service is okay. But would go back for the pizza and take to go

Family loved the pizza... as this is the in law's favorite pizza.
All kinds of toppings.
No restrooms.
Cash and Card accepted.
Everything done fresh.
Slice $1.50
Whole pie $ 18.00 (cheese / pepperoni)
Made variety of sodas, juice, water.

After a night of adult beverages and dancing nearby came across this corner pizzeria. $1.50 plain slice...nothing fancy just simple and ready to eat!  Although there was a line, the service was quick and in and out in less than 10 minutes.
Very good service, nice and cheap, really quick, lots of choices of slices authentic New York pizza

I got delivery from here through seamless the other night. 2 Bros isn't the best NY slice, but they are open late and the pizza is good! I like their white slice the best. The globs of ricotta are IT!

My issue with this past delivery experience was that the one slice had some tomato sauce on it. This sort of defeats the purpose of white pizza, so I was disappointed that this was the slice I received. However the pizza was fresh and hot and the delivery was on time!

I will definitely get a slice here in the future when I need some quick eats, but it isn't a place I would seek out.

If you want a quick bite and enjoy great pizza at a ridiculously cheap price. This is the place to be.

Sure, no where to sit and eat, and if you're lucky enough you may be able to share a high table with others. These guys just make pizza , where and how you eat it, is up to you. But do they make nice pizza for a first cheap price !

The food quality/quantity/ value is high/high/high!

Get there early, as the queues can be quite long.

It was a good slice of pizza for the price, but it is not a place I will be returning too. If you are in dire need of some quick pizza, this is the place.

I ordered a pineapple pizza  that was reheated and given to me slightly cold. The convenience of ordering was great since it allowed us to walk out quickly and eat on the walk.

The service was quick and the food is already made prior to the visit and is just reheated. It means some parts of the slice were cold, however it was a $2.50 slice.

There is seating inside so that you can eat the slice there. We ended up going to another place to try some pizza and we realize the major difference in quality even though the other place cost similar.

Very fast service. No frills and open air spot during the summer. No line on a Wed night. The traditional sausage and pepperoni pizza was only okay, lacking flavor and salt. At this price point, would definitely try a different type of pizza here, the squares looked good!

Hijos de puta la próxima vez denme una bolsa plástica cabrones  iba por todo el camino cagandome en sus madres ,,, las pizZas saben buenas pero parece que se lo muerden por no gastar,, prefieren darme una bolsa de papel 4 pedazos y si yo fuera manco donde me las meto? en el culo???  ,,, cabrones tienen que pensar que uno no solo lleva las pizzas también llevo el bulto del trabajo de ruedas e iba por todo el camino odiándolos,,, ya eso era todo,,, puñeta compren bolsas plásticas  o de tela que uno pueda llevárselo tranquilo y sin agobió ,, enserio  o si no no vuelvo a comprarles pizzas prefiero ir al de mas adelante que si me dan bolsas que uno pueda llevárselo tranquilo  parece que se lo muerden por no gastar o a lo mejor ustedes tienen bolsas pero parece que las guardan para dárselo a los cAbrones blancos
Save your money. Buy a donut or literally anything else. Pizza was so bad. Not good processed meat.

A staple of New York is of course the pizza and nothing is better than $1 pizza. 2 Bros has many locations all throughout the city; this one is close to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in the Midtown West area.

Because the $1 pizza is so popular they always have whole pies ready in the oven to replenish their supply. If it's been sitting out for a while they'll put the slices in the oven to heat them through but if you're lucky you might get a fresh slice right out of the oven. Their cheese pizza is pretty good but it tastes even better because it's only $1.

There's just something about giving the guy at the counter a dollar and he gives you a slice of pizza. It's like magic.

Very mediocre cold pizza that's not as cheap as others you can get elsewhere. Got a Sicilian slice with pepperoni, sausage, onion at about midnight on a Thursday night. Line was fairly long but moved fast. All the pizza was sitting out for a while & they reheated it but it was still cold when I got it. $6.00 for cold pizza but it still hit the spot!
Solid cheap slices. They advertise $1.50 slices outside but the menu doesn't reflect that deal.

As a complete tourist and someone who doesn't necessarily understand the whole pizza slice culture, I basically pick my places based on cost and location. There are too many different preferences and options for me to pick otherwise. This happened to be the place I passed by on the way back to the hotel I was staying at. The slice I got (Buffalo Chicken) was $4, though I think cheese was $1.50. They also had garlic knots at 50 cents each. Otherwise, the place was like most of the other pizza by the slice shops. The pizza was fine for what it was. A quick, cheap bite to grab on your way from or to some place exciting.

Came here during a long work day, saw a sign on the door for the 2 cheese and a soda for 3.00 dollars. I thought, "no way is that right. I paid 10 dollars for a slice of garbage and a seltzer two blocks up the other day"

Friends, It was right. And it was fresh. And the cheesy was stringy. The sauce was saucy. The dough? Foldable like a perfect NY Slice should be.

My only complaint is I didnt find this place sooner!

This is likely the best of the 2 Bros which is a good thing as it's right nearby Port Authority but it doesn't mean it's good. It likely stays busy from all the tourists as well as commuters going to Port Authority. The slices have gone up in price but it gets the job done and it's hard to argue with the price unless you're in Flushing or Chinatown where there are a lot more better options. My favorite of the cheapo slices is the 99 Cent near W4th but this is solid. It's fine.

YUM. This place was next to our hotel and we went every night. 2 slices for $2.99!! I was about it. Sometimes if you want a New York slice at a NY pizza place you just get cheese but we tried other flavors and they were good too! My personal favorite was the mushroom and pepperoni- it hit the spot. They also take Apple Pay!
Quintessential nyc pizza spot with multiple locations. Fast, inexpensive and delicious. The perfect amount of crunch!
A go to pizza stop in NYC - cheap, quick, and tasty! The line moves pretty quickly and there are a lot of options to choose from - 10/10 would recommend for your new york pizza bite.
I had a mushroom slice here. The taste was pretty mediocre, but the service was quick and the cost was low. Good option for a late night slice.
First time trying pizza from New York. Best pizza I've tried! Super tasty. Fast service. Cheap price. I keep coming back everyday
Best pizza on the block how many characters do you need to tell people the pizza is good

Great pizza in the east coast. Came to visit NYC from Sacramento and enjoyed the pizza. I shoo'd away couple lingering bums that kept buggin to enjoy my pizza ( but forget about it) I didn't see any Giant rats that I hear roam the streets but maybe they're training turtles but this cool city to visit on Citaz. It do remind me of Frisco ( San Francisco) but it's little bigger. Was hoping to hear " hey I'm walking hear" lol

I've downed slices at so many of these $1 pizza slice places I'm almost embarrassed to admit it.

Almost. Hey, it's a dollar a slice! It's pizza! Always a good way to cheap snack.

Anyway, it's a 2 Bros Pizza joint. This chain is pretty reliable with their $1 cheese slices. Decent taste. Large slice. Make it a meal deal of $2.99 for two slices and a soda.

It is what it is. Cheap pizza.
This place is insane. I ordered over the phone and when I got there they hadn't even started cooking my pizza. The place is crammed and dirty as well. People walking through it, just yuck!

I had this pizza 3/4 days I was in town  I mean it's open until 2am and they were 2 minutes from my hotel.

But not only is in convenient, it's good too! Clearly I was hungry lol.

Buffalo Chicken, Veggie and the cheese are all really good! The veggie is top tier tho. My friend didn't like the bbq.

Also, the cheese pizza is $1

First time in NYC and one of the items on my food to get is NY Pizza.  On our way back to the Hotel, we noticed a line at "2 Bros Pizza" so we decided to swing by and get pizza to take back to the hotel.
I wanted to see what's all the hype is about with NY Pizza. We took it back to our hotel (a 5min walk away). It smelled good walking to our way to the hotel.
First the pizza slices were the size of two paper plates and they were $2 -$3.50 I think, depending on what toppings you got.  The pizza was not too saucy and the crust was soft but yet had a little crunch to it. All pizza flavors was delicious, now I'm not a fan of buffalo chicken pizza but the "2 Bros Pizza" was good even my step daughter loved it and she is a very picky eater.
I would say this first real NY Pizza was a great experience and 2 Bros Pizza was very quick and easy to go pizza place to stop at.  I do plan on visiting NYC again and if I stay near the area I would come here again.

Their Pizza was great.  It was an incredibly large Pizza.  There was so much Pizza - I could not eat all of it and saved about four (4) slices for the following day.

I really enjoyed 2 Bros Pizza.  Fantastic.

This was my last night in town and I was looking forward to getting some NYC pizza. It's almost can't miss, right? Well, I ordered a pizza from 2 Bros Pizza and was surprised that it was actually going to get here several minutes earlier than Uber Eats has initially suggested. I understood why that was after I got the pizza. It was ice cold. Obviously, it had been sitting around for at least a couple of hours somewhere and I guess they figured, "Why not send it to a tourist? They aren't going to be back here regularly." That's just wrong and the people that run this place should feel bad about themselves for doing this kind of thing.

2 Bros Pizza is great. If you're looking for a pizza join with cheap, good pizza that is served quickly then look no further. They have a wonderful selection of pizza varieties that all look scrumptious. The store itself is incredibly small and crowded which can be an issue at times. There was a homeless guy by the register begging for money, disturbing the line, and coughing all over the place and nobody felt the need to kick him out. If that hadn't been the case, this would be a five star review.

Hard to complain about $1 pizza! It's a great pit stop while rushing to Penn station. The crust is thin and crispy and a slice is nicely packed with flavor! The smell and price will lure you in, just let it happen.
The pizza is cheap hot and delicious. The service is quick and friendly. The pizza is light on sauce (that's how I prefer it). The crust is thin and crispy.

Loved it. I took my family to get slices. We all got different flavors. They were all great. Even the broccoli one.
There was a lot of confusion there with other people in line and ordering at different times, but they kept it straight, and got all of the orders correct.

One of NYC's best bargains, you can get 2 slices & a can of pop for $3. So I often make it rain & buy 4 slices & 2 cans of pop.

Line forms to the right, ladies.

Seriously though, while this wasn't the closest location to my office in Manhattan, that one could have lines stretching well out the door, so I'd sometimes walk to this one that was somewhat less crowded.

Very affordable, semi-decent, pizza.

DO NOT COME HERE.

My friend and I came here last Sunday evening, it was pretty crowded. We each got 2 slices. They were alright, nothing special. We both got diarrhea from it. It's a week later and we are still getting diarrhea. We both went to the doctor and found out we got E. COLI.

IF YOU WANT DIARRHEA FOR AT LEAST A WEEK EVERYTIME YOU EAT AND RISK HEALTH COMPLICATIONS DUE TO E. COLI, THIS IS THE PLACE TO GO.

I am never coming back to this grimey spot. I don't normally leave reviews but this needs to be known.
Pizza was amazing and the pricing was excellent. I had the two slices of cheese pizza + soda combo for 3.75 and it was well worth my money. Crust was excellent and pizza was well prepared.

This pizza was so great!!
So glad I stopped by. Grabbed a slice of pepperoni. Crunchy and delicious !! 10/10 would eat here again.

My fave dollar slice pizza place in NYC! I always get either the dollar cheese slice or if I'm feeling extra fancy, I'll get the $2 pepperoni slice. The consistency is real here - every slice tastes the same every time and I'm never disappointed! Not sure what to eat for dinner? Want a quick snack while you're walking? Want a second dinner? 2 bros is for every and all occasion.

The pizza is not bad but they will scam the hell out of you. They do not have prices for anything except cheese and make up the price as they deem fit. I paid $30 for a large pizza while another man right next to me paid $20. When I said something about it they looked at me and just walked away. Again pizza is pretty good but be careful with those prices.

Very much just okay pizza that does not even come close to other New York pizza offerings. The main draw is how cheap and fast it is, but with the same amount of money you can just go down the street to Joe's and get a much better slice. Service is also quite curt.

The slices are unremarkable and greasy with quite a bland crust and very average cheese. Honestly I would probably only come back if I were dying for a slice of pizza and absolutely no other options were open but otherwise, I'll pass. Being in New York means it's important to respect yourself enough to eat properly good pizza-- never settle for less!
Not worth the price of a pizza pie in NYC! No taste and it was cold when I picked it up!!

Gotta love New York's $1 pizza! Some locations are better than others but I definitely recommend this one. Only the plain slices are $1. If you want toppings or a grandma's slice, it'll cost you around $2.50 or $3.50. They don't very clearly advertise the prices of the slices with toppings so beware.
I ordered 2 plain slices. Some of these restaurants charge tax on top of the price but this one was $2 flat! I paid in cash so not sure if that made a difference. The people in front of me paid with a credit card so this place does accept cards.
The slices were great. Classic New York style. Some $1 slices have a very thin crust so they are not satisfying but this was a solid, full size slice. The crust was thick, especially towards the bottom of the slice. I was very full after eating only one and a half slices.
This location had a few tourists and was a bit slow. They have a deal for 2 plain slices and a can of soda for $2.99. You can't get a much cheaper meal than that in New York. Enjoy!

Very cheapPizza makes anything possible. ...
Anyone who says that money cannot buy happiness has clearly never spent their money on pizza. ...
There's very little in my world that a foot massage and a thin-crust, everything-on-it pizza won't set right. ...
I want pizza with my face on it.

Average pizza that satisfied the pizza cravings - this is fast food with quick turnaround. We saw the sign on the window for 2 slices and a coke for $2.99. So we decided to try it. We didn't read the fine print and we paid $10 for 2 slices of white and 2 slices of sausage - NEITHER was eligible for the special. Cheese only.

The gentlemen behind the counter (brothers?) were working hard for the money. One prepared the dough & pizza toppings & baked. The other took orders, reheated the slices, boxed them, and delivered the goods to the customer who paid whatever he said. Fast. Efficient. No making nice with the customers. Plain and simple.

It's on the corner. It's open air. There are some tables and chairs inside. Don't expect much and you'll be satisfied.
Great pizza and saved me while I was staying at a close hotel. Staff was fast and friendly.

This was my first experience at a street cart. It did not meet my expectations. I got lamb over rice and the rice was the only thing that was good about it. The lamb had little chuncks of burnt crunchy lamb mixed in with it. Maybe it was just bad luck to get the one not so delicious meal they served that night, but street carts are common enough where one bad experience can turn me away for good.

Could not wait to eat cart food in NYC.

The smell of Gyro was making me insane, so we stopped here. The guy was actually very nice and added absolutely everything I wanted to my gyro.

It may seem ridiculous to give a little Halal cart 5 stars, but I'm a Jersey Girl who simply does not get the kind of food that these great little food carts provide all of you lucky people in NYC get to have all the time.

It. Was. AMAZEBALLS OF FALAFEL.

What's to like:  Cheap, Large portions, delicious.  $5 for Chicken or Lamb over rice.
What's not to like: I've got nothin.
What to get:  Get the chicken over rice with both red and white sauces.
Final thoughts:  In my opinion, this is the best street cart in NYC.

Once again i got the lamb over yellow rice. The meat was a little dry, but I went kind of late and it looked like it had been sitting there a while. I was hungry and this was the closest cart at the time so I went for it. The rice was average (bland but at least soft), the portions were good, and the price was good. $5.
The portion size was small for a halal cart. It's not like the ingredients were top notch to offset that. The lettuce was browning...
Price is now $6. Its as good as any other halal cart in the city. The rice was a little tough. There are better carts for $5.

Food was delicious and the service was even better. Quant speakeasy restaurant. Prices were very reasonable for the delicious food!

I would recommend this place any day!

Nice, cozy quiet spot, with a rustic feel. The interior decor didn't seem to have a cohesive theme, as there was an antique rifle on the wall which didn't go with the rest of the place, yet there was still a certain charm to it. The seats were comfortable and the white tablecloths gave a classic, slightly more sophisticated atmosphere.

I was trying to decide between the lamb ossobucco, grilled pork chops, and three-cheese steak. I finally picked the lamb, which consisted of a huge piece of lamb shank, served with roasted carrots, onions, and mashed potatoes. There was a lot of meat soaked in tomato sauce and it was quite good. The meat was very tender and came off the bone easily. It was flavored well, but there was a bit of an aftertaste that I didn't like much. I definitely prefer grilled rack of lamb. The vegetables were wonderful, though - Fresh with great seasoning! The mashed potatoes were delightfully creamy, while the sauteed julienned cucumber and carrots had a distinct and yummy garlic taste.

My friend and I shared two desserts: Bread pudding and apple strudel. Both of these desserts were plated beautifully. The bread pudding was served warm, surrounded with cinnamon cream and had strawberries and whipped cream on top. It was delicious! The cake was sweet, doughy, thick and perfectly chewy. It melted in my mouth and the cinnamon cream went with the cake famously- Also sweet and very rich. The apple strudel came with vanilla ice cream, a bit of strawberry, sprinkling of powdered sugar and pretty dots of chocolate/caramel sauce. The crust of the apple strudel was flaky and crunchy and there was plenty of apple filling with a bit of cinnamon taste. It was pretty good, but I think I preferred the bread pudding.

The service was attentive. I would consider coming back, but wouldn't go out of my way to do so.

An interesting choice especially when it comes to the burgers

*Note* My review is based on take-out only.

Food: 3.5 Stars
The Champ Burger: Half pound of black Angus beef steak burger.
I ordered this burger medium-rare but received a bizarrely cooked burger. Half of it was medium-rare and the other half was medium-well. The crazier part of this the cooking difference was vertical, not horizontal. I don't know how they managed that.
The burger wasn't juicy, but the meat was tender and not dry.
The toppings you can choose from are interesting if you feel a very mildly adventurous (And I mean mildly). I took the "Olives Sweet Fried Onions" thinking the fried onions were from a brand called olives or something else. However the dish included fried onions and olives. It seems like a weird combination, but it worked.
You have 10 choices of cheeses for your burger. I went with my standard mozzarella, good choice as usual.
The fries are above average.

Fish and Chips
It took me a while to find a place that has fish and chips (as well as a place where I can be lazy and order it online), but 1 Vizio has it.
The fish was fresh and well cooked. The batter was crispy and had a nice golden color. I will be happy to order it again when I get a craving for it

Service: 3.25 Stars
Standard service. I received my order and I was offered a seat while my food was still being prepared. They staff was polite.

Speed: 3.5 Stars
The first time I went, I arrived about 20-25 minutes after ordering and my food wasn't ready yet, but the second time after showing up 15-20 minutes after ordering, my food was ready. I don't know if this was inconsistency, bad luck, or they weren't sure if I would show up or not, but overall I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes after arriving at the restaurant.

Ambiance: 3.5 Stars
1 Vizio is a pretty small restaurant. Since I have only ordered takeout I am unable to tell if the restaurant has more of a homey feel or just I'm eating out at a restaurant feel. It isn't very crowded during the later lunch hour (past 1pm).

Overall: 3.49 Stars
I found this place  while digging through yelp for a good burger and wasn't disappointed. The assortment of foods on the menu at a decent price will have me going back often.

1 Vizio seems like a good place to seat down and eat if you are going to a Broadway show nearby.

However if you want good takeout and feel like spending a little ($8-$15) you should try this place out.

I don't feel comfortable giving 4 stars as of yet, but as I continue to eat here I feel I will raise the rating.

This is one of the only places I was able to find a huge selection of different animal burgers: black angus, buffalo, turkey, ostrich, kobe, salmon, bison, wild boar, venison, elk, and lamb!

****- Ostrich burger with bleu cheese and caramelized onions- absolutely delicious. Trust the waitresses when asking for burgers. The flavor is unlike any normal poultry, instead more akin to the flavor and texture of mammals. Ostrich is totally layered with flavors. There is an aftertaste which I utterly enjoyed, but my guest did not--so it is a personal taste, but we both agreed this was the best burger we had. Definitely a delicious, healthy beef-alternative.

***- Wild Boar burger with sweet fried onions- A deeper flavor which seems more natural, it's that flavor they say wild animals sometimes have. It doesn't taste like a pork at all. The texture provides an interest, compact yet juicy experience. This is also a good alternative to a hamburger, with a different appeal and theme. Just be prepared for the slightly woodsy flavor.

** 1/2- Venison burger with mushrooms and provolone- This definitely has a wild, woodsy flavor to it. I've had some sweeter venison, so it might have been this batch. The burgers flavor is less intense and subdued. The color is actually intensely red, and the burger is drier than we expected. Overall it was a weird experience. You definitely need to be a fan of venison to love this.

Atmosphere-
This restaurant has simple decor, almost European in ways. They use brick unlike wood-paneling which is used extensively, already giving this place a different feel. I enjoyed the paper tablecloth and crayons to draw with--it's easier to clean up, and takes away from class, but I crave entertainment, too. Amusingly, we sat next to their huge Vizio plasma screen television, too.

Service-
They were nice, helpful, and patient answering our questions, and I never felt rushed. Although they weren't too interactive, they were always present.

Amenities-
If you do take-out, it does seem popular. Literally, every five minutes someone was leaving with a take-out order, obviously not people that Yelp, right? It was a constant back and forth action, which made me wonder just what everyone else was ordering.

Conclusion-
Take-out seems like a good option if you can't get here, or find it--because it is a little off the beaten path. I'd want to try all the burgers if my stomach was big enough. Three burgers definitely filled our tummies with unique and different animals. The restaurant does crave to promote healthy eating, and these alternatives can be interesting and delightful, too. Vizio, find it and eat some animals!

Don't miss this little gem. In a city filled with restaurants (many overrated and overpriced ) this is one you want to add to your list !
Cozy upscale atmosphere. White table clothes accent the meticulously clean room. A wonderful mix of music from Dylan to Marley to jazz accompanies the eclectic menu. With a nice selection of seafood , chicken ,meat and more there is something for everyone. Even a burger if you want it.
My wife and I loved the Mediterranean sole. Cooked right and accompanied by vegetable and Potato for under $20.
Dessert list was lovely and also reasonable. The chocolate brownie and ice cream was yummy with freshly brewed coffee.
The wine pour was extremely generous with a decent wine list by the glass. A fine meal in a lovely setting.
All in all it is worth checking out.

Well, let's rate as I wait....how about that? I walked in at 8:20, waited till 8:23 for someone to greet me. The greeter was very jolly and it felt nice and homey. I waited till 8:30 until I was about ready to leave when the waiter popped over apologized. Took my order and was back quickly with my wine and water. So far, so good. Order went in at 8:35 and food (chicken parmigiana) was done so fast.

Food was wonderful! The service was great from here on out. They made me a believer and I'll leave my attitude at the door next time!

Great food!  Ordered from them using the Eat24 app.  The delivery was on time and the food was still hot.  The rosemary chicken was delicious.
Only downside was that they got the side dish wrong, but we ate it anyway.

Imagine that the only food left in the world came in burger form.
And you're hungry. And you want to eat.
What kinda burger are you feeling?

Bacon? Cheddar? Swiss? Mushrooms? Onions?
You are SO Boring.

How about Elk? Venison? Wild Boar? Ostrich? Lamb & Mozzarella? Kobe Beef? Salmon? Buffalo? Now we're talking.
Oh, you still want bacon, cheddar, mushrooms, etc? We gotchu.

Don't forget to try it with avocado or goat cheese!

Had the venison burger - it had a slight hint of game but was seasoned just enough to make that a feature, not a flaw. The sesame seed bun was perfectly sized and toasted. The egg wash gave it an extra crispy texture.

My darling had a salmon burger with avocado. She's a fan too.
We ordered sweet potato fries to share - they're a must.

I intend to come back for the rest of the animal kingdom.

Delicious and well priced!

Veggie burger was $6.95 plus tax and sweet potato fries were $3 or so.  I think the veggie burger is one of the standard patties made with spinach, peas, carrots, soybean, etc.  The reason for the five stars is the nice service and huge selection.

A couple friends got bison and kobe burgers.  I don't remember the exact prices for those, but they ranged from $8-$14.  The other two got the $11.95 brunch special which include food, coffee/tea/juice, and a bellini/mimosa.

The Burger Update:

I remain, Yay! I'm a Fan.

We tried a couple of burgers at Vizio a few nights ago.  The girlfriend went for the straight up beef burger.  I rolled with the ostrich burger.  Burgers were cooked nicely medium rare (actually, I could've take mine a touch rarer but, it was a bird...you know the rules about cooking poultry).  They brought them to us exactly as we wanted.  For the lady, Beef was nicely medium rare (she would have let them know, if it wasn't) and it came with the slice of onion and on a nice, hearty whole wheat bun.  For me, the ostrich was very tasty, served with a slice of mozzarella on the same whole wheat bun.  Let me say, any place that offers you a whole wheat option earns instant points with me.  These buns were nice, almost artisan, hamburger buns - good tasting and substantial.

Sweet potato fries, score!  They were nice and light and not at all oily.

As an added bonus, we tried the hummus plate to start.  Hummus was good and garlicky and super smooth.  Only disappointment was the pita chips it came with were pretty salty.  

Vizio qualifies as a reliable eatery just north of the theater district.

Ordered here several times and today was the last one

-I cut my tongue on an inch long wire that was in my spinach.  My tongue is swollen and bleeding. I used to really like the spinach here too! But apparently it should not be attempted unless you have a metal detector handy.  Sitting here with blood in my mouth, hungry, seriously considering suing this place.
-the flounder is completely tasteless
-the beet salad is CANNED BEETS sliced over some greens, are you serious?
-the sole is just NOT fresh at times

Completely subpar.

The lack of a zero star option is a real dick move, Yelp, because that's what I'd put here. You know what though, I'm not mad at ya, Yelp, it;s not your fault. I'm sorry I brought you into this crazy mess.

My coworkers and I had Vizio delivered to our office (roughly 8 blocks away) for a glorious hump day feast. They advertised burgers of all different genus and it seemed pretty righteous, actually. I ordered the bison, but am bummed I made a quick decision and didn't opt for the ostrich, venison, or boar...but it wouldn't have mattered.

They estimate delivery for 12.....well no how about 12:30 now. Still hungry? At 2:45 the guy comes rolling into the office with a partial order and i pick up my "Chipotle Bison Burger" for which (at the time) I am still somewhat pumped up about.

The wrapped burger, to the touch, felt pretty cold - like, colder than room temp. No matter, I've made worse food scenarios work before. I have moxie. I CAN eat cold burgers.

But. Not. This. One!

I took one bit and it tasted like metal. The burger was like if you had overcooked a Topps frozen burger, left it outside all day, and then served it after rubbing it on a car bumper. I spit it out (I never do this) and threw the burger away. I then abruptly grabbed my jacket and headed out for non-rusty-and-cold-burger.

I actually left my office before the delivery man was even done sorting it out. He had a lot to sort out. Don't ever get food from here.

I have only been there twice but did i love it! Both times were for brunch but I really don't think you can do better for a brunch in the area on a saturday or sunday!

Brunch runs till 4 PM on both days of the weekend so you could do the entire weekend if you wanted! They have a list of about 12 or so meals and may i say i recommend the eggs benedict.

Here is the best part....you get the meal, coffee tea or juice, and a mimosa or other breakfast alcoholic drink all for $11.95!!!!

I haven't been there for the other food but it seems to be a good. The place isn't huge but i have seemed to always get a seat (depends how big the groups are). Also depends what you order..i had a friend who ordered the french toast i believe and was still hungry but then again this is a kid who eats.

I would def check out this place if you are looking for a small nice little brunch that isn't costly at all.

Long time ago, I dated a guy who was into 'rescuing" failing restaurants. He would take me to these places, where we were the only ones eating. The thing was that most of the time, these restaurants had good food. Maybe it was the location, the bad neon signs, whatever - but inevitably, these restaurants went out of business.

This place reminded me of those dates.

I ventured out tonight looking for a place to eat. However, it's just too freakin' cold, so decided on the place half a block down from the hotel.

Tonight, there was only one other person dining. I went with the prix fixe menu which consisted of:
1) Garden salad or chicken noodle soup (I went with the chicken noodle soup)
2) Some meat dish or penne pasta with chopped up clams (you can guess what I went with)
3) Bread pudding, chocolate mousse or ice cream for dessert (I picked ice cream).

Before the soup, they brought a couple of pieces of garlic bread. They were NICE. Not too buttery and not too garlicky - toasted to the right texture. I was hoping this would be a good sign of things to come.

The chicken noodle soup was a bit bland but it was clear that it was homemade. There were plenty of tender pieces of chicken with long noodles floating in the soup.

The Penne pasta was cooked perfectly (i.e. not al dente ) but the sauce was WAYYY too salty even for me. However, there was generous amount of chopped up clams. Good quantity of food.

Finally, the ice cream was served with whipped cream on top - a nice touch.

Overall, a nice dining experience at a small neighborhood place. Good value for the buck. The service was friendly. Would I come here again? If I'm staying at the same place on another cold day, then yes. Otherwise, I might venture farther to seek better options.

The last few orders have been overcooked and late but the one this week takes the cake. There wasn't one part of the order that was correct. The Venison burger came with the toppings and bun for the buffalo burger, including raw onions that I specifically asked not to be included, rather than the French toppings. The burger labeled buffalo was, in fact, the venison burger, which my husband didn't realize until he bit into it. He hates venison. The actual buffalo burger came on the wrong bun with no toppings whatsoever. The salad was supposed to have blue cheese, but instead came with feta cheese and olives. Also foods my husband hates.

When we called Vizio there was no one who could assist us. While they did offer to remake the meal, we didn't want to wait another 40 minutes for their mistake. We asked for a refund instead, but no one there was able to accomplish such a thing. They told us to stop in when the owner was there, although no one seemed to know his name.

This restaurant used to be a favorite, but we have noticed a severe decline in quality. Needless to say, we will not order from them again. I cannot in good conscious pay someone for a job done so badly. Their suggestion that we should "stop by" is the best they could come up with is ridiculous. It took a call to Seamless to fix it. Seamless, BTW, rocks.

We have been to Vizio a few times pre theatre and it was decent. Last evening it's as simply horrific.  They took forever to get our order then the Salas's were late and out entrees even later. The restaurant was Nearly empty so real excuse. Further the had no fish option except for tuna which we ordered. It's was over cooked and dry and the onions were chopped and not carmelized as described. My wife has a hanger steak with chimichuri and arrived again overlooked and inedible. We sent back and it came back raw. All side for sides the same and bland.

When we complained wait staff said new cook only 3 days and they were sorry. Offered no apologies or discount.

Clearly this place is in trouble. Food not fresh and no real chef. The price is high and you get junk.

Avoid

Being I could not rate this place 3 1/2 stars, I've given Vizio the benefit of the doubt, and rounded up to 4.  The biggest saving grace is simply this: the burgers rocked.

Price was decent, starting at $7 for classic, veggie, and turkey, with add ons such as bacon, cheese, carmalized onions for $1 - $2 bucks each.  Only downside is that a side of fresh potato cut fries (which were very very good) are separate for $3.  Still, you definitely will get your dollar value on these burgers.

Delicious, beefy, and satisfying are only a few words that describe the taste of their classic hamburger.  I added bacon, swiss cheese, and onions to mine, which made mixed in perfectly.  The hand-made patties are grilled on an open flame, and right in front of you, if you happen to sit farther back in the small establishment.  If you like your burgers a little juicy, I suggest having it cooked one level above what you think you would like.  I ordered mine medium, and it came sweating.  Still, with the added mess, very tasty.

Not the best place for groups larger than 4.  But certainly a roomy, intimate atmosphere to share with 1-2 people.  My only complaint was the wait.  Granted there were 4 of us on this particular outing, it took a considerable amount of time to get our drinks, let alone food.  But, it's semi-understandable, being that Vizio only sports one small quasi-open cooking area.  The staff was very friendly, though our waiter was a bit absentminded.  Overall, a recommended place for anyone looking for a great burger.

just ordered an "organic" burger cooked medium on a potato bun with sweet potato fries. here's what i got via my work meal ordering platform.

1. what appeared to be one of those cheap, buy in bulk frozen burger patties you bought when you were in college (no SHOT this was an organic burger), cooked whatever is the temperature above well done (dry? so well its bad?) on a KAISER roll. a freaking kaiser roll. the gigantic, dry bun that should only ever be used for a bacon egg and cheese (and even then its questionable). burger stunk too.

2. a single Hunts brand ketchup package. first, why in the world are you using hunts ketchup?  you haven't heard of heinz? second, am i supposed to use one ketchup packet for the gigantic dry bun and shriveled up burger, and all the fries? seriously?

3. not a single napkin. a burger and fries, no napkin. yes, i did check the box requesting napkins. no, i did not get napkins.

when i called the restaurant to ask what was going on (namely, why i was staring at a breakfast sandwich with a burger in it) i was dismissively told "oh yea, we're out of potato buns so we just give people kaiser rolls. how in the WORLD is that your default response and default action. first, why wouldn't you call the customer to ask them what they want? and if you're too buzy/lazy/inconsiderate to do that, why are you defaulting to a freaking kaiser roll instead of just a standard sesame bun? is the kaiser roll that much cheaper for you? the guy who answered the phone also thought the appropriate response was "is there really a difference? do you really care?". seriously?

This also cost over $20.

unbelievable. absolutely will not be ordering from them ever again and will let my entire desk know about my experience. will also be posting this review to our work ordering platform. awful.

FOOD POISONING AT VIZIO

I have never written a scathing review before but this place has forced me. We walked in about 8:30 pm last night and the place was empty. The service was good as they didn't give us trouble about 2 late friends (again, it was empty.)

I looked up the menu online and was craving the salmon burger (which I've had many times before in other places.) I should have paid attention to the signs as the burger was tiny, the bread was the stalest I've ever had in a restaurant and the salmon burger while didn't taste funky, was dry. Something was a bit...off.

As I am the only one who ordered this from my group I have been since 2 am vomiting and etc and this is possibly the sickest I've ever felt in my entire life. They have robbed me of a relaxing day, all my plans, and my health. PLEASE STAY AWAY!

I eat salmon every week and have NO allergies to anything so this was a bit shocking to say the least...

This place has cool burgers for cheap (bison/buffalo/ostrich) with great toppings to add.  They also serve sweet potato fries which really hit the spot, and their regular fries are skinny and good too.

Unfortunately, the decor is really weird, the place was empty so that made the atmosphere all the more depressing, and my sister's burger was totally overcooked and burnt.

Hit or miss ?

Maybe next time, ill get this stuff to go, and ask them to undercook my burger.

We had tickets to a show in New York at 254 54th street, so we scheduled dinner at 1Vizio prior to the show. We arrived earlier than our reservation, but no matter, our table for 6 was ready . We ordered the onion rings and the calamari friti as appetizers as we decided on our dinner. While both were good, the onion rings clearly won the day as the best of the two. We also ordered 2 glasses of cabernet, and for $5.50 we each got 8 ounces of wine. Excellent deal and the wine was good. One of our party ordered  the fruitilicious drink and that was also very good.

For dinner, we had a wide mix of choices, and we chose the salmon special, mac and cheese, pulled pork, lamb osso bucco, grilled chicken pecan salad, and the champ (black angus) burger. The Tuesday night special is free small fries with a burger - perfect. They do have a venison, and bison burger as choices as well.

As I have written before, I am on a low sodium diet and I always ask the waiter to do low sodium meals, and that was no problem.

Finally, it was dessert, and we had 2 orders of brownies with vanilla ice cream, tiramisu, apple strudel with vanilla ice cream, and ice cream. The brownies were very light, not the best to eat alone, but worked fine with the ice cream. The strudel was very rich with apples and cinnamon, and also worked well with the ice cream.

All food passed the yummy test and the total came out to around $30 per person for drinks, appetizers, dinner and dessert for 6 people.
Excellent, excellent Bison Burger!!!  Juicy and thick!  Great sweet potato fries!  Bargain too!

What an awesome find in this neighborhood. The nicoise salad was fresh and very high quality. And I'm not sure what the reviewer below was talking about--my Kobe burger and my husband's skirt steak were AMAZING. Plus the dynamite shrimp were crispy and awesome. We were so full but the food was so great we had to take the bread pudding home.

The service was not great, but not insulting or anything. The waitress literally had her phone earpiece in while she was serving. For this area the food is great, the portions large and the prices are VERY reasonable. I am so glad we found this spot.

Somewhere out there 1 Vizio was given four (4) stars... Not sure how that happened!!  To begin with, we arrive for our 7:30 reservation (Thursday evening), and we are the only people in the restaurant.  Is that a sign? Our waiter was not friendly or helpful at all!! And, except for the Beet Salad, the food lacked flavor!! The salmon entree was overcooked; the (Fantastic) meatballs needed a lot more seasoning; and the hamburger was blah!! I am so sorry I wasted one of my dinners in NYC at 1 Vizio!!

Delicious sweet potato fries, nice comfy cushion seats

Went here cuz I had to run an errand at Kinkos (Why do faxing docs cost so much? But that's another review). Found out they have sweet potato fries. I never actually tried that b4, yet it makes so much sense to me. So I got that along with a Philly Cheesesteak sandwich. I ordered it at the store, and got it to go.

It is a small store, but it has a nice ambiance. The first you recognize after looking around a bit is the old 18th century rifle on the wall. That was really cool, kinda felt like I was in a museum or something. While I sat and waited for my order, I noticed the seats are cushioned and are quite comfortable.

It took about 10 minutes, but I got my order and went back to work and eat. My work place is a good 10 min walk from the place, and the fries were barely warm by the time I got it back. The cheesesteak was a bit soggy from soaking up too much juices from the meat. But surprisingly, the food is still pretty good. I love the sweet potato fries. It has the crunchiness like regular fries, but has a sweetness and the texture like a sweet potato. I never needed any ketchup for them cuz they already taste great.

The cheesesteak also tasted pretty good. The way they make it is different from others. They used American cheese and laid 2 slices, 1 on each 1/2 of the sandwich. It was throughly melted, so you can't recognize it at first. Some ppl might complain about the use of American cheese, but I don't mind and I really like how the meat mixed with the peppers. It would have been even better if I had the meal at the restaurant.

Today was a snowy cold day, so I tried out Vizio, a local restaurant not far from my job. Delicious stuff! Had their rotisserie lemon chicken, it came with mash potatoes and veggies. My fave was the sweet potato fries!

They do deliver.

I had lunch here yesterday with a colleague and it was absolutely fine.  Her fish and chips seemed good, and my bison chipotle burger with cheddar was just what I wanted - something basic, simple, and acceptably executed.  The fries were pretty good, and actually the onion rings we got for our appetizer were fantastic (yesterday was not a healthy day).  The prices were really reasonable for what we got.  

My only complaints were that they only had honey mustard, not spicy brown, and when we paid, we asked for the server to put part of the check on a card and bring change back for a $20 - he instead took the remainder of the check out of the $20.  Not a big deal, but if there was a reason he couldn't fulfill our request, he should have told us, instead of doing something entirely different.  

If you want something simple, basic, and reasonably-priced close to work, I'd recommend this place.  Wouldn't travel to eat here though.

Had a reservation for 10, we were seated right away.  Waiter and waitress were very nice and attentive.  Food was awesome, we got the bison chipotle burger, and goat cheese and apple salad.  Only down side is no liquor license, but they had great beer and wine.

This place was alright.  Nothing special.

I had the spaghetti and meatballs and my girlfriend had the ostrich burger.  My meal was a little sub-par.  I've had better food at low-end diners.  I had a burger earlier that day so i wanted something else... I guess that's what I get for not ordering a burger in a place known for them.  Next time I'll know.

I had a few bites of the ostrich burger and it was very tasty, well-cooked and had all the right condiments and ingredients.  The fries were also pretty decent, not to greasy but a bit too much salt for my liking.  

Their beer selection was a little scaled back.  No tap, only bottles, and only about half a dozed to choose from.  And the service was a bit on the slow side.  

I'd try this place again if the opportunity came up, just to see if it was just a bad day and give them another chance, but I would probably not recommend this Vizio right now to my friends.

this was a nice cozy place and the food was alright, but worth going at least once for some exotic menu items.

i had ostrich burger and my friend had elk burger. i don't know if my moderate interest for burgers affects my normally exemplar taste buds, but i honestly could not tell the difference between the two meats or even from beef (except that beef would have a stronger, "beefy" taste)

didn't get a chance to, but supposedly the smoothies are good.

might want to try the kobe burger (at $14.50, i think. which isn't too bad if it's real kobe) and some champagne next time (this meal might sound classy yet down-to-earth haha)

also noteworthy was that both waitresses were very friendly and patient. we took a while to even order drinks, but she was patient.  friendly service can ALWAYS contribute to a good dining experience even if the food isn't sublime!!

and it's nice that they have specials everyday. ex. shared the hummus as half-off appetizer (w/ ordering a main course) today that it only cost $3.25! the hummus is quite good too because the romaine that accompanied was i think mixed with raspberry vinaigrette!

Tasty sweet-potato fries, limited beer selection & ostrich burgers make this place worth considering... though not a sure-fire hit.

After yelping the place, I came in with quite the appetite (just finished working out).  Now, I finished everything, so the flavor was there... but I have to criticize the veggie burger.  It, well, fell apart.  It's not an uncommon problem, sadly.  No one quite nails the texture on these things.

The restaurant was empty -- it was a Monday night.  The server was happy to be of help, even changing the lone TV for me.  However, I feel as if this place is lacking that something special to take it above average.

After wandering around looking for a place to eat before a show at Terminal 5, we took a look at Vizio's menu and peeked in to see that THEY GIVE YOU CRAYONS - sold!

Our order was taken right away, and while we played tic-tac-toe, a plate of garlic bread was brought out. A bit too heavy on the garlic and oil, but still good.

We both got Kobe beef burgers with goat cheese (not a menu cheese choice, but they were accommodating). They were nice and juicy and very tasty. Also pretty big compared to the other burgers in the area. It wasn't my favorite bun in the world, but it was good enough. Came with some sort of sauce that was green(? might've been the light) that I didn't go near. Our request for honey mustard was met right away.

Fries had been fried too long, but are plentiful and cheap. If I went back, I don't think I'd order them again. Actually let's say when I go back! Would definitely recommend.

P.S. Very attentive service and taking our time, we were out the door in about an hour.

Where to start.... I wish there was an option to give zero stars so one will have to do.

Service was kinda bad, it took almost an hour to get our food and we were two of 4 people in the entire place.

We could have complained about every single thing that came out. My diet coke tasted awful and it came from a can so to me that's weird that it would taste bad. Oh wait the soda expired over a month ago maybe that's why. We ordered the hummus. We did not get garbanzo bean hummus it was more like a red or pinto bean hummus garnished with onion and peppers I believe and had the color of refried beans. We order tuna nachos. The menu stated it was fresh tuna and mozzarella....yeah not so much. The tuna was greyish in color and dry so it was not fresh and it was covered in what tasted like blue cheese dressing not mozzarella. We ordered the Kobe beef burger.
