The chashu's flavor was REALLY good, but it was chewier/drier than I would have liked.

I saw pictures of the Black Panther Curry ($26) before, so I ordered this as well. Kind of pricey for the quantity, but I expect this is because of the ribeye. The ribeye was tasty - it had good texture and flavor, cooked just right! The squid ink fettuccine was fine, but I didn't like how clumpy it was (hard to separate individual pasta strands without picking up a large chunk with it). The curry itself was exactly what I was hoping for and very tasty.

If I came in with the focus only being the food, maybe I would have rated this place more highly. Unfortunately there were more factors to this establishment to consider, and the restaurant performed less well in those areas.  

The first (smaller) issue was the service. My party made a reservation ahead of time, but when we arrived, there were no tables available. The front of house handled this pretty well however and brought us to the bar to sit and wait and look through the menu since a table was clearing out shortly.

After we were seated at our table and ordered, my party noticed that the food comes really out slowly - albeit not as slowly as other reviews have mentioned where it's an hour+ wait. The wait was maybe 40 minutes, but it was frustrating because we already spent time waiting before then even with a reservation.

When the food was finally served, they didn't provide a spoon for at least the ramen (I like to have a spoon for the curry as well). Upon asking for spoons, they provided them with bowls promptly. However, with the earlier issues it was hard not to notice the lack of attention to detail.

While waiting for the table we ordered drinks at the bar, which I (wrongly) thought were going to be the stars of the night. The first drink was a Sua Smash ($16), a familiar tasting drink with an extra herbal hint assumedly from the Thai basil. This drink was fine, but not extraordinary.

The second drink was the Knockout Tiger ($16). I regret getting this drink. The pandan and smoke combo was interesting - I was not expecting a sweet ingredient to be mixed with smoke. Not quite a fan of this combo. The smoke is way too overpowering - I couldn't standing putting the drink to my face for too long and couldn't way for them to take the glass away since the smoke smell still lingered around it. Would not recommend this drink.

Overall, the food is good but the establishment is noisy (makes it hard to chat), overcrowded, and has some underwhelming drinks in which I was only barely able detected the alcohol in them (abnormal for me, I'm usually a fan of drinks being LESS strong).

I wouldn't come back here in a hurry, and if I did, it would only be for the food.

Let me start off by saying that I love a good speakeasy with creative and fun drinks. 11 Tigers definitely gets a B + for that. I think what I wasn't so impressed with was the food and customer service. We came during opening time on a Sunday and it seemed like they were basically out of everything on the menu.... What they did have though, was subpar.

The waiter, oddly took our order at different times so some people had appetizers come out at the same time as someone else who had an entree. They never came to check on us afterward, which was a bit disappointing.

I gave this 2 stars for the drinks and the aesthetics of the speakeasy... I'd come back for those 2 things if I'm in the area - but definitely wouldn't eat here again.

Came here with a couple of girlfriends and had a wonderful experience.

My gfs and I came in around 2pm on a Saturday afternoon so the place wasn't packed yet - there was only a birthday party going on and a couple of tables but other than that, we could hear ourselves talk.

We ordered a couple drinks off their menu and one of them had a spark/fire so that was pretty cool! Service was fast and courteous so we didn't really have a problem. Our experience was pretty top notch so can't really complain.

Would return to try the food next time!

My first impression at 11 Tigers was that the service was not great. While the appetizers we ordered were overall actually quite delicious, the service is the reason it's 3 stars and not 4. While it tries to be drink-centered, it was quite food-centered and this disconnect was quite evident. The energy was fun though, the servers would bring a tiger mask to guests that ordered shots and drink with them.

I saw this place on TikTok and came here with a couple friends while visiting NY. We ordered a couple appetizers.

11 Tiger Karaage: it was so good we ordered it TWICE
Takowasa: if you love seafood and wasabi, you have to order this app
Look Chin Pla Pling: fish balls that weren't flavorful whatsoever, do not recommend
Age Sake Kawa Salad: good! I love a good crispy salmon skin.

Cocktails were good, but not amazing. I really enjoyed my Sua Saming, would recommend. Wish the service and drinks were better. I would come back for the food.

Have been here twice now and the food is consistently good. May even be in my top 3 izakaya spots in NYC (and love the Thai fusion on it too). Favorite food items include both styles of karage (chicken + squid) and the 11 tigers Mentai pasta w/ uni (it's like a spicy, briny, creamy carbonara). Also really like the tuna rice cracker (not pictured, since had in a previous visit). Also portions can be generous - so do yourself a favor and come with a group so you can try as much as possible!

While the service is friendly, my partner and I did feel a bit rushed (both times). With the last time being a bit frustrating, knowing that if we put in our entire order, they would just have dishes come out as ready, rather than space them out. Of course this happened (and felt a little pressured to put in the entire order as quickly as possible) and to the point where a.) There was no room left on the table and b.) They took some dishes away that werent finished (and sad too because there was one I was saving a little bit to pair later on in the meal).

Despite the above, I will absolutely be back due to how consistently delicious the food and cocktails are!

Thai & Japanese?? Love the concept. Love that there's uni in dishes. Love that there's curry. Love that their cocktails are really good! The 11 tigers mentai was SO good. Black panther curry was also a highlight of the night. Golden uni sashimi was so small but I loved the smokiness that accompanied the uni! Would definitely come back.

Cocktails - get the tiger killer - pandan, passionfruit, pineapple, coconut!

Came by for dinner on a weekday evening, when we arrived around 6pm the place was mostly empty (we did make a reservation) and then it was packed by 7pm. They have unique cocktails and Asian fusion food items. We really enjoyed the mentai udon, scallop & uni hand roll and stone rib eye (though this one was a tad on the pricey side for $16 for the size). They do smoke the ribeye in front of you when it comes to your table which was pretty cool. If you get the Bad Kitty on Fire cocktail, it has flaming cinnamon which they light at your table so a literal flame on your drink! We also had the takoyaki -- which was fair but nothing too special. We were hoping to get the Tiger's jewel box options but they didn't have it the night we went. We also had the oyster shooters -- you pick the flavor -- which was tasty.

All in all, it's a cool vibe and everything is "tiger themed" from the drink and food names to the decor (super cool mural in the staircase leading up to their entrance). The tables are a bit small if you order a lot of food, but most people were there for drinks -- there is a small bar area, but mostly small tables with a few "lounge-y" seats, but most of the tables are made for small parties (2-4 people).

The food was delicious at 11 Tigers! It was pretty consistent from appetizers to entrees. And the cocktails were also very good. However, I would advised against the wagyu steak option. There is only 3-4 small pieces in the bowl and the portion size is VERY small. It should really should be an appetizer, it's that small. Other than that, the atmosphere was fun, and my friends and I had a great time! We will definitely be back!

Wonderful new speakeasy!
It was quite busy so service seems a little..delayed but food and drinks were excellent.

I got the black panther curry and my fiance go tthe tom yum ramen. Both dishes were PACKED with flavor and actually quite filling.

I don't think you can go wrong with any of the cocktails. The presentation is also on point. Get the "bad kitty on fire" for a little table flare :)

Very cool looking restaurant/bar in east village next to stuy town. We came here for a nice anniversary dinner and were surprised by the beautiful tiger murals leading up to the entrance (second floor). The tiger theme continued inside the restaurant with more paintings and little tiger decorations everywhere.

The food was also great (Japanese izakaya). I had the unagi don which was very tasty. My bf ordered one of the drinks (knock out tiger) and it was just as much of an experience as it was a cocktail. The waitress lit a scented paper on fire and then covered the drink to trap the smoke and scents within the drink.

The waitstaff was very attentive and checked in with us often. I really appreciated the great service, and they were obviously working hard to give each table enough attention.

Overall really cool looking spot, perfect for date night or if you're just looking for a fun experience.

I like this restaurant! The location is a little bit off the busy areas but worth the trip. It's a Thai/Japanese/pan-Asian fusion place. Come here before 7pm for happy hour. The food is pretty good. A lot of creative dishes and everything tasted great. The drinks are cool. Many nice cocktails with cool presentation. Good service and good vibe.

Came here with my husband and an out of town friend on a Saturday night after seeing a really cool Insta ad about a "new, cool speakeasy" in the heart of Alphabet City.

The food and drinks were both really good (more details on them below). But a speakeasy it is not. Besides the entrance being not easily accessible because you need to climb a flight of stairs to reach it, I think of a speakeasy as usually have a more subdued, chill vibe. But the vibe here is more of a cross between a club and a lounge - not only was it pretty packed but it was super loud - I had trouble hearing my companions who were seated across from me and next to me. And maybe because it was so popular, the service was a little "hands-off" in the beginning of our visit. After being seated and getting water, no one came to take our orders for the next 20 minutes.

Yet despite all of that, I did still really enjoy my visit because the food and drinks were excellent and the prices were very fair for NYC. I would probably just come back on a weeknight in the hopes that it's less crowded and less clubby.

Of the three drinks I tried:
(1) Pink panther is probably my favorite in terms of taste - this lychee-forward cocktail was pretty sweet but well balanced
(2) Kitty on Fire - this is the drink of the influencers. It's not just a drink but comes with a whole show - not kidding, it's like a half minute flambe light show where our server asked all of us to move three feet away for safety purposes. The drink itself was a good mix of refreshing, tart, and sweet and a whole lotta cinnamon. Would definitely order again just for the light show.
(3) Tiger killer - for all its fruity ingredients (pandan, passionfruit, coconut, and pineapple), I thought the drink was very spirit forward and slightly bitter. Lovers of pandan would definitely like it.

The food was also really good! We got three things to share:
(1) 11Tigers Mentai -  this creamy pasta dish with cod roe and uni was SO AMAZINGLY YUMMY that I'm still thinking about it a week later. There was also quite a generous amount of uni. The cream sauce is a bit thick so I don't know if the taste would get cloying if you ate it all yourself but split between three of us, it definitely left us wanting more.
(2) 11Tigers Ceviche Mixto had quite a kick and got spicier with time but the seafood was very fresh
(3) Crying tiger steak - the ribeye steak was good and I like that the texture was a little crunchy from the sesame flakes. I've had more tender ribeye in the past but the hubby loved it and thought the natural flavor of the beef really shined through

I've been waiting for cocktail bars like this since I moved to NYC and I'm so glad that 11 Tigers is now on the list.

Here's what you need to know:
1. Make a reservation. This spot is getting popular so lock down your time when you can.
2. The drinks are delicious and strong. Order them all and remember to stay hydrated.
3. THE CURRY WITH SQUID INK PASTA. Absolutely top tier. Get it immediately.
4. Tuna laarb... absolute banger. Also get this one.
5. Drinks can be slow to come out so I recommend ordering as soon as you get a chance
6. Nice vibe that is aligned with other NYC bars.

Crazy good food. I got the honey lemon chicken; roasted with big sprigs of rosemary, perfectly seasoned. Also the mac and cheese had this amazing breadcrumb crust with a little curry kick that was amazing. ALSO probably the best collard greens I've had in NYC.
I didn't drink there, but the beer and wine selection seemed solid.
On top of all that the staff was super friendly.

The food was well flavored and delicious! I would recommend for sure! I had the crab legs, Mac and cheese, shrimp cocktail and collard greens. The owner was really nice as well. Drinks were great. And a plus is that they have a great selection of vegetarian and vegan options like the unchicken tenders, vegan Mac and cheese and vegan collard greens.
The best macaroni and cheese I've ever had. Bomb chicken and waffles. Fire music. Can't wait to go back to try everything else on the menu.

Great food and great service. They give you good portion size and the food taste amazing. I got the surf and turf which was a special that night and it was amazing. The server was also great as everyone said. Would totally recommend

Writing because I just tried their VEGAN Mac and cheese and it was so good . I've always seen the place , but originally stopped one day when I saw vegan Mac and cheese on their board . Food was great enough to fill you up . And they have more Vegan options ! Which I'm sure are all amazing and will soon hope to try , it's a cozy atmosphere just a regular place to lounge relax and eat

What a fantastic place! we stopped by last night for a few drinks. The service, the genuine care, the quality of drinks was amazing. You could sense how the owners truly want to make you happy. When i will be in the area again, I will come again!

This is a small nice intimate place that is both restaurant and bar a little off the beaten path. That being said, the place was much better than I thought it would be. The macaroni and cheese was very tasty, you could taste the different cheeses throughout. I opted for the chicken and waffles which tasted like it was made with love down south. The cook makes everything fresh so everything is warm and gooey when it gets to your table. The spiked lemonade was a nice drink that complemented my food well

Went for an event! Place is a total dump! Definitely a hole in the wall! Served Sangria straight from the supermarket and their "Three Wishes Wine" which in reality is a $3 bottle in Whole Foods wine shop...was charging $11 per glass...Total rip off! Food I can surprisingly say was ok...but to be honest this place totally sucked!

5c cafe is one of the lower east sides best kept secrets.....the pics need updating though because the place looks modern  they have a great jazz & r&b singer(me) and many other artist that perform there ..oh and the food is off the chain my favorites are their quesadillas...mac N cheese....shrimp n grits....bbq wings ....shoot i love them all!!!!!!

Great Food! Chef Calvin has magic hand, whatever we ordered had amazing taste. I do not usually eat Mac and Cheese, but I could not stop eating the dish. Even simple egg sandwich had a lot of flavor, love the herb he used on it. My quesadilla was very crispy and tasty.  The grits and fish was too easy to eat, I have to go back there to eat that again. Super nice staff and love the piano they have. Thank you for let us play.

5C Cafe and Cultural Center is a neighborhood gem; it's a truly folksy living-room type space where you can relax with a sandwich and latte and dig some great jazz. Trudy and Bruce have been in the neighborhood since the days of Slug's (legendary jazz bar on 3rd street) and the building 5C is in was once home to Allen Ginsberg.

For the club's entire history, the owners have been hounded by their landlord, who has been trying to get them out of their corner space on 5th street and avenue C. In spite of that, they have given back to the community with educational programs--Trudy is a teacher in the NYC public school system and a piano graduate of Berklee; Bruce is a jazz historian--and exemplary entertainment programs. On my most recent visit, I saw the amazing Bob Stewart (of the tuba quintet GRAVITY!!!) in a trio with his son Curtis on violin and Jerome Harris on guitar.

Food is fresh and reasonably-priced; there's only a $5 food minimum, so this is an excellent, welcoming place to hang out.

This place was a surprise and a half. The food was excellent, and the service was homey and genuine. My friend and on ordered from the vegan menu and were shocked how delicious and well prepared it was. The restaurant looks very casual and unassuming, but don't let that stop you from thinking you'll get a top notch meal!
Mac & cheese on point  great people here. Wine champagne beers. Vegan options on point too best around with so much favor. Great music.
Amazing food and service. This is like a hidden gem in New York. Spectacular service, great relaxing jazzy vibe! We will definitely be back!

Vegan quesadilla!!! OMG delicious and very generous portions. I appreciate a place where the staff is friendly, the food is good, I can work on my laptop and no-one bothers me. Good places are hard to find in this town anymore. I will be back!

I had one of the best meals I've had to date in New York at 5C Cafe. I got the Meatballs w/ linguine - which was INSANE. My sister couldn't decide, so the chef legitimately let her customize her plate. She got chicken, shrimp, collard greens, and macaroni and cheese. All of it was phenomenal. If it is even possible, the only thing that might have topped the food was the service. Everyone was so friendly and the vibe is super laid back. I would eat here every night if I wouldn't gain 10000lbs by doing so.
This place is the East Village's best kept secret. Cheap beer, incredible food, really nice staff and an awesome Jam session on Tuesday night. Come!
Where do I start? Oh, THE FOOD!! It's amazing. Delicious and fresh and the staff is personable and friendly. Will 100% be back for the Mac and cheese and shrimp and grits!!! Yes, yes and yes!
Great food here great music great vibe and the people who work there are great friendly cool and music is great...the food tho is the best I had so far really really good...
The owner of this cafe is really nice. Their food is really delicious. Especially the chicken salad! Had a great time there!
The chicken and waffles are amazing. Friends got the roast beef and mac and cheese and it looked and smelled delicious as well.
Hours quite variable. Lately it's open 7-7. Still jazz concerts. Free wifi. Great neighborhood feel!

I stumbled across this place on a psychadelic evening and it made my week. An amazing jazz band was playing and the vibe was unbelievably laid-back and civilized. Relatively cheap wine was being sold and you can just curl up on the sofa and soak it in. Looking forward to going back.

Great Jazz, Delicious Snacks, Warm Atmosphere

What happened when five seasoned NYC musicians collectively known as LightStreams came together on a brutally cold January 30th 2010 night in the cozy 5C Cultural Center & Cafe on the city's lower eastside? Great jazz--both standards and many original compositions by Jeff Franzel (piano). The rest of this stellar group of pros was made up of Jerry Dodgion (alto), Chip Jackson (bass), Bobby Routch (flugelhorn), and Andy Pastorino (drums). These musicians all have independent performing and recording careers and have shared the stage with many jazz legends. (Google their names and see the impressive lists for yourself.) But when they jam together as LightStreams, there is a magic, camaraderie and a sense of play--they trade musical jokes throughout their songs. These guys are a pleasure to watch and their musicianship is topnotch.

5C Cultural Center & Café is a great value. It is an inexpensive place to hear jazz and they serve delicious vegetarian snacks, plus fruit drinks, wine and beer--all at reasonable prices. I had the handmade deep dish mushroom pizza that was spot on!  The service was fast and friendly--the café's comfortable atmosphere was like being in a living room with friends.  

LightStreams fearturing Jerry Dodgion will be playing at 5C Cultural Center & Café on February 12. -- posted by Don Gabor

This place is great! Their food is delicious - best pizza and mac & cheese ever. For drinks you can get anything from a latte to a beer, & it's all reasonably priced. The owner is so nice, too. They also have local musicians play which is really cool - sometimes it's a singer & a guitar, sometimes a jazz band. The only slight problem I had is that they're cash only, but it's inexpensive so it's not a huge deal.
Lovely laid-back cafe - real neighborhood feel, and all the coffees/pastries you could want. Stumbled upon in the daytime but will definitely be returning for the live music!

The owner and staff at this cafe were very friendly and cooperative. We had a great time shooting a film project here, and the food was fresh and delicious. Definitely recommend this for a film location if a cafe is needed.

The owner of this cafe was lovely to work with. We filmed a student film here on a Sunday and she made sure we had everything we needed and lots of coffee so we could finish our film. The cafe had a great vibe and I would love to go back.
Good cheap pizza, especially if you get the deal (2 cheese slices and pop for $3.99).

Price went up 50% quality and attitude went down 100%
Pizza sucks now and the attitude of the dude there sucks even more
Never ever ever will I go to one of these places again

I had a very dear friend visiting NYC for the first time and one of her requests was a cheese slice that NY is so well known for.  

I am in East Village pretty often and had stopped in many times before for a late night slice on St Marks Place. This establishment is no frills...especially at night when they close the inside and you are not able to sit.  But that is no problem as there is a countertop adjacent to the cash register that you can lean on and it has all the spices/seasonings that people like to put on their pizzas. I knew that this was the place to bring her.  We were having dinner nearby at a nice place and I also remembered that 2BROS are open pretty late so the timing was actually perfect.  

There was no line and I just went in. Just a couple of people at the counter closes to the entrance. There was a displace with other slices like chicken and other toppings but we were not there for anything fancy. I asked for a plain slice which was approximately $2 and the employee promptly got the pizza and I paid.  

We turned to go lean against the counter and she proceeded to put some spice seasoning and white pepper on her pizza and took a bite.  She look so happy and savored every bite. She seemed to enjoy the pizza more so than the food at the restaurant we had dined at just before.  

This was the simple pleasure and NY experience she was looking for and it made smile (and hungry) to see her enjoying the slice. I was tempted to snag a bit of her pizza but I wanted her to enjoy the whole slice because this is a common slice for those who live here.

Depending on how late it is, there may be some seedy individuals around or rowdy people.  Luckily there was neither when we were there and the staff was diligent.

This place is not fancy but recommended for a quick and cheap slice of pizza....especially for anyone who would be visiting the city for the first time like my friend.

We have been going to 2 Bros for years! Out of all the dollar slices you can get in the city, 2 Bros is one of the best considering the price and the quality. We usually order the pepperoni pizza, it has a nice thin crust, has also a nice charred to it, and is easily foldable. The balance of the sauce and cheese is good, a bit on the salty side but again worth the price. The pepperoni was flavorful. Nothing beats quick service. Overall, we recommend 2 Bros for anyone who is seeking a quick and delicious pizza fix, and the pepperoni pizza is a wonderful option.

It's a 2 bros location. If there's no line you're in and out in 30 seconds and you have a warm slice of dollar pizza in your hands. There's not much to complain about. The guy is always there making fresh pizzas and the person behind the counter is nice. Size of the slice can vary but it's usually pretty consistent. It tastes good, a little doughy in the crust if you want to be critical but it's literally a dollar. I come by if I want a snack on the way home from work.

Food: comes to your cheap New York pizza, 2 Bros Pizza does the job! Place was everything I expected and I loved it. I ordered two slices of pizza and a soda for dirt cheap. It was ready in seconds and it was delicious. The crust was very crunchy and the slices were gigantic. 2 Bros Pizza is definitely my favorite cheap NYC pizza spot.

Other: there are a few tables inside. There are also a few high top counter areas where you can sit and eat. Overall there's not too much space there are also standing tables outside. This is where I ate my pizza. Great spot but not too much room to stay and eat.

0! TRANSPHOBIC they attacked my bff and catcalled her
DONT GO HERE! terrible service.

Two Bros Pizza may not have invented the dollar slice concept, but they definitely ran with it.

I dropped by the spot on St Marks before a night of carousing in the East Village and, while inflation has driven the cost up a whole dollar, it's still satisfying.

Is it the best pizza you're going to find in the neighborhood? Hell no. But it's a good contender for best of the dollar slices

I cruised by at around 11:15 am, hoping to score my cheap lunch, but, the place wasn't even rolling with any pies yet.   I like beating the lunch crowd, and I just don't understand store hours as we're emerging from covid.
Either you're open at 11 or you're not.

I came in on my own at an hour where the store was completely empty save for a single employee. The pizza was perfectly fine. It was a dollar so no complaints: size wise was a good portion and was better than other $1-2 slices I've had. The sauce was a little tangy and the crust was thick so if that's your preference you'll enjoy it though I imagine if you're coming here for a slice you're not really going for enjoyment sake, just necessity.
The reason for my low rating is because of the service. I got my pizza quickly and all that but I found the employee's behavior very unprofessional and somewhat prying. He invited me to sit at the indoor seating at the back of the store which I had thought was out of courtesy so I would not have to stand but later realized it was so he could ask me a series of highly inappropriate questions.
"Do you have no friends?" I was on my own so that's where the presumption came from likely and I took it as a joke so I wasn't offended by it. I shouldn't have entertained it by responding but I did because I had thought he was only being friendly. He then asked me where I worked, if I lived in the area, what time I got off work, what my name was, suggested I don't work too hard because I wouldn't have time for my boyfriend (which revealed his intentions all along because I obviously had not insinuated a boyfriend since I didn't really answer him), asked if I HAD a boyfriend, then asked if I wanted a boyfriend and if I would have him as a partner. I just left at that point.
Man I was just trying to eat my pizza in peace lol.
It was definitely uncomfortable but mostly just a nuisance and even for a dollar pizza there's no way I'm coming back to this particular location again.
They sell $1 pizza here and it is amazing! Bread is very soft and served fresh and hot, free add ons. People are very nice too

Easily one of the better dollar slice places in Manhattan. It's also located on Saint Marks making it a great place to get a quick and filling snack after a night out. The person at the counter was very nice and polite, and I got my pizza very quickly.

TL;DR: this place has all the elements of a great NY pizzeria
Idc about the pizza - the staff is disgusting! They were transphobic and rude. Avoid this place!

2 Bros Pizza is one of the most recognizable Sliceria chains in Manhattan. Unfortunately, it has never impressed me. In a city with so many places to get a fast and delicious slice of pizza, I see no reason to stop at 2 Bros. They pizza, for me, is simply adequate. Their slices are not what I look for in a slice of New York Izzy. Of course, this is a highly subjective matter, but I have a particular issue with their crust. I like crust that is doughy with a subtle crunch. I also like the end crust to be big. 2 Bros crust is somewhat cracker like, almost as if it is dry. This is common across all of their slices. Regardless, their toppings and sauces are not bad, I would even say they are around average. With so many great pizza spots nearby in the East Village, I would walk the few extra blocks for great slices at Artichoke Basille's, Sauce, or East Village Pizza.

Cheese Slice (2.5/5): This cheese slice really disappointed me. Their cheese has the artificial texture and taste that I dread. It had none of that chewy and stretchy flavor and texture that I know and love. I also can't get over their crust, it is just too crunchy and dry. It may be the preference of some, but it is not what I look for in a great fast slice.

White Slice (4/5): White Pizza is my favorite slice of all time. It is hard to complicate and luckily their White Pizza is not that bad. If it weren't for the crust, I would give this a higher rating. This mozzarella cheese is better than the cheese found on their traditional Cheese Slice. I still would not rank it is highly as I do other options in the area...

Veggie Slice (3/5): Their Veggie Slice, much like their Cheese Slice, is average. Their toppings are what you would expect and perhaps the portion size is even a little larger than average. You can still tell that the toppings are not of great quality and the crust was just like what I experienced with their other slices. My favorite Veggie Slice of pizza in the area is undoubtedly at still at East Village Pizza.

I got the $1 cheese slice which was not bad. The dough looks thick but when you bite into it it's actually really soft. I would've still preferred it to be a little thinner but for $1 it's a decent slice of pizza.

They have other pizzas toppings that cost more than $1.

It's mostly standing room but there are also some tables in the back.

This pizza is amazing. It is just pure genuine NYC pizza! Coming from Miami this spot hits the spot!  great big slices and quick service.

The pizza has great flavor and I love the dough. Everyone here was nice and the restaurant was clean.

Will come back to have more next time I'm in town!
Nasty as pizza didn't even wash there hands and they were so rude to my friend for no reason, don't go here it should be closed

Idk what y'all expect out of a dollar slice of pizza. You get what you pay for, and for $1 this is actually an awesome slice of nyc street pizza.

You really can't be complaining when you get two slices of cheese and a soda for $3 even.
Quick service and the pizza is consistently fresh and good . They make their pizza from scratch and for a buck you can't beat it .

There really is nothing out of this world about the taste of the pizza, but it is by far one of the most reliable spots you can find after a late-night bar crawl. It's also super affordable and quick so I would recommend it for those reasons alone.

These pizzas are fucking delicious! And holy heck these ginormous slices can be shared. I made the mistake of ordered two for myself . Try as it might, and as much as I wanted to finish them I just didn't have enough room in my tummy. This is giant New York pizza like it should be. Only complaint is that service is pretty awful, the workers get impatient and annoyed if you don't make quick decisions lol so make sure you know what you want before you go!

Wow what terrible pizza. Figure I'm in NYC so pizza is always good, right? Wrong. This pizza sucked. No sauce to speak of and I asked for extra sauce! Crust on body of pizza wasn't thin or floppy. Boy what a disappointment. Never again. Two Brothers....oh brothers!

2Bros is where it's at for a quick and cheap meal. Not much else to say when a regular cheese slice is only $1. By no means is this amazing pizza but for the price, it gets the job done to fill you up. The slices are a little thicker than your average New York slice. There's a slight crispiness in the crust with a light layer of tomato sauce and cheese. Be sure to sprinkle on some herbs, red pepper flakes and garlic powder for extra flavor.

This is a great location and they're open late so it's especially convenient for those nights out. Store itself is narrow with some standing space to eat along the wall or you can opt to sit in the back where they have a couple stools, benches and tables. Don't expect it to be the cleanest, just quickly eat and go.

I had the chance to visit this 2 Bros location after grabbing a few drinks with a friend at a nearby bar. It's not as common as it used to be to find an honest $1 slice in Manhattan, especially in my UWS neighborhood. However I was happy to find this cheap pizza enclave that's surprisingly open from 1 to 2 AM the majority of the week.

My friend and I walked in around 8:30 on a Monday evening. There was no line and we were able to order and get our selections in just under four minutes. The restaurant has a sizable seating area in the back where we parked ourselves and dove into our pizza slices. We both got just regular cheese but in all honesty they were prepared so well! Not too hot and not too sloppy of a slice, they held well and weren't drenched in oil. Overall what you want a NY slice to be.

Given the area this location definitely seems geared towards the college crowd. On the weekends it must be insane but if you're in the area during the week and craving a casual slice I definitely would take the chance and walk in. You won't regret you did.

Solid $1 slices to soak up the suds.

No line on a weekend afternoon, just breezed on through.

2 Bros is a classic pizza place - there wasn't too much that jumped out at you, but as soon as I bit into it, somehow the cheesy-ness hit me with a nostalgia that took me back to my childhood. The cheese pizza that I ate was pretty good -$1 and hit me in the feels.

Would recommend for its taste and price and a little trip back to the classic cheese pizzas you would have as a kid at big birthday parties. Loved it

Cheap, simple and delicious!! You can't beat cheap NY pizza that is fast during the lunch hour and warms you right up during a chilly winter day. I had the buffalo chicken pizza which was piled with tender, spicy chicken. Drink options are canned soda or water bottles. They also serve pasta here but I don't know why anyone would get that. It's a simple place with limited seating, but come on, it's a dollar slice place so not sure what you were expecting. Will definitely be craving their slices again.

Tip: They don't really have a sign outside but you can look for one of those folding boards advertising their special of the day in front of the door.

This pizzeria it's great so if you see one stop by inside. The pizza are cheap $1 great if you're on a budget and want NYC style good pizza. They always have soda combos and 2 slices , pies are under $8. They have locations here in NYC, Brooklyn and the Bronx. They cater to special events. One of my favorite pie is the broccoli and white pie , Hawaiian pie for my pineapple lovers and the meat supreme pie which includes sausages, ham and assortment of vegetables.

You can also get by the slice $1 again!! it's quick and delicious. I been to a couple of locations late night after a night of drinking both the ones in west and east village have the same consistency so it doesn't matter which one you go to. The only thing I would say the one in Times Square it's always busy but line does move fast. There's no seating in most of these just the counters to stand up but I have seen small round table in the ones in midtown.
yoooo as a person who grew up in the tri-state area i take my pizza slices, seriously. and this $1 slice rose to the occasion. five freaking stars.

wouldn't recommend this place at all!! worse pizza place in town!! pizza was stale and cold. customer service was horrible. took forever to get one slice. spend your money some place else with real quality pizza.
I'd say this is the best dollar slice still out there. They even take credit! What more can you ask for? Prime location near great bars, fast service, and a piping hot slice of NY pizza.
AMAZING DO NOT MISS!! Dollar slice from a different world. Cesar up front is very kind and fulfills his role with integrity. Thanks all!!

2 Bros is easily my favourite dollar pizza establishment in the city. Perhaps I'm wearing rosy glasses when thinking back fondly, but 2 Bros has been there for me like a loyal friend, moreso, even. When I got hangry at my first boyfriend and stormed off - 2 Bros was there. When I thought the Japanese portions around the corner were too small and still starving - 2 Bros was waiting. When I biked 50 miles around the city and needed to nourish my body the true New York way - 2 Bros nursed me back to health. When I was exhausted from a night of drinking and dancing around the east village - 2 Bros did not judge me as I stumbled out of their doors with a slice and peed on the subway tracks while waiting for the D train home. Bottom like, I'd make 2 Bros the godfather of my children if I could.

Unlike other facsimile dollar pizzas, 2 Bros is the original that doesn't skimp on quality and sauce. The mark of a true slice for me is one that has a flat crust, raised on the perimeter slightly but still has a crunch, with just the right amount of sauce so that you get a little tomato smoothness with every bite. When you do it wrong, it's just either a cheese tomato sandwich, or worse yet, a piece of cardboard with marina smear.

5 stars goes for Nostalgia, quality, and being the best friend a New Yorker can get.

To all the idiots that think this is a new york slice... it isn't... its the dollar slice... like seriously what did you expect... good service? good pizza? no, this is for broke and hungry people that wouldn't mind eating cardboard with dry glue on it.

Its pizza slices for a dollar! The slices are good and they are made fresh since everybody buys these slices! Its in St. Marks there are homeless people that hang out there. If that bothers you, you don't need to eat these dope cheap slices. Buy a slice and give a slice (its a $1, if you can.)

Great for if you are drunk in St. Marks or just starving and have a dollar.
It's been my grandson dream being a pizza lover to get pizza from here and finally after many years in the making here he is !! You guys have a real fan in San Leandro califronia

Could be the worst pizza in the city? The cheese is barely melted. The bottom of the pizza always burnt. If you are drunk and looking for a cheap slice, come here. But honestly, the 99 cent pizza shop is a lot better in taste lol. There is just barely any flavor, IDK maybe it is supposed to taste like healthy pizza? These remind me of the frozen Elio's pizza, but microwaved. And Elio's was probably better

Lived right next to this 2 Bros location and slowly became a huge fan of the pizza here. Almost nothing tasted better than two $1 slices of 2 Bros for a midnight snack. Most of the time I got pizza that was piping hot and the cheese PULLED. Granted, it can get a little sketchy on the sidewalk/street in front, but at that point I was used to the craziness of St. Marks. The staff at the counter aren't the friendliest but you can tell they deal with all sorts of people they don't want to have to deal with.

Definitely a staple in the poor college student's diet.

Basic pizza at an affordable price. I only came because it was hot, I was hungry and the shop that I wanted pizza from had no pizza slices I wanted ready. I found this place on my way to the train station and realized that this shop has other locations that I've never bothered to eat at. To my surprise the pizza wasn't bad. The location is small and it looks literally like someone dug out a whole in a wall and decided to make pizzas out of it, while adding just enough space to have a couple of seats in the back. I felt like I was underneath somebody's porch. The white pizza I ordered was 2.50, and was just enough to fulfill my appetite. Thanks to the drink I got from Whistle and Fizz, I was cool and alright. I wouldn't say I would never eat here again at this location, but its definitely not on my bookmark list.

I love this quick 1$ slice . To me as a New Yorker , pizza is important . You can't go wrong with a dollar slice or 2 slices and drink for 2.75$. Every time I am in the city I stop by , takes less than 2 minutes to pick up a slice . Hardly any wait , and always fresh . Slices are selling out so quick they keep making fresh hot pies.

For $1, you get exactly what you ask for: a slice that isn't amazing, but is satisfying.
If I had to give reviews based on truthfulness of advertisement and fulfillment of expectations, this would get a five; however, I am trying my best (though not well I think) to grade based on the quality of the taste and overall enjoyment; therefore, I will give it a three.
A tip: don't expect comfortable seating. The seats are sparse, but you can always walk to an area nearby; I think there are benches around, so that shouldn't be an issue. Also, they didn't have - or I couldn't find - any napkins, so try your best to avoid touching the pizza directly or bring your own napkins.

It wasn't the worst of slices, it wasn't the best of slices; but it is definitely a slice that I would get again.

What can I say about 2 Bros that hasn't already been said? This was one of my regular spots back in my youth, after a night of drinking. Actually, it's still one of my regular spots, even with no drinks in my system (if I'm in the area and am craving some pizza, which is all the time). I've only ever tried the plain slice here and it's pretty good for a $1. I'm not sure why it has such mediocre reviews. Like I said, IT'S A DOLLAR. Obviously, you know you're not getting gourmet artisan pizza. You could do a lot worse than 2 Bros.

my friends and I were in the area to go to another place for dinner, but it was super packed and the wait was over an hour. we decided to walk around to see what else there was and stumbled upon this pizza place! prices were decent for these big slices of pizza and the bottom was perfectly toasted w a v nice crunch. I got the chicken pizza which was actually super yummy even though it looked like fried tofu. the workers weren't the nicest, but I can cut them some slack since there were only 2 of them and a good amount of customers. the seating area could use a good clean, but I guess it's fitting for a quick stop pizza joint. glad I was able to try this place even if it wasn't my initial intention!

I came in here to grab a snack after volunteering. I ordered 1 cheese slice. It was all heated up.

The sauce had good flavor and the pizza did not have too much cheese nor sauce.

We swung by on a Sunday afternoon and there were a few people lining up. We grabbed a slice of cheese pizza for $1. You cannot beat a $1 slice of pizza. That is hot, chewy cheese on a plate served to you that will fulfill your dreams of getting cheap food at a cheap price.

For the taste, I will most definitely eat this pizza over $10 Dominoes or $5 frozen pizza or any other non gourmet pizza. Why? Because it is hot, chewy, $1 pizza served to you on a plate when you have walked 10 miles in Manhattan and tired and poor. Eat this pizza, enjoy this pizza, and I think a person really shouldn't complain about the quality unless you find yourself literally sick after eating it.

I recommend the cheese because it's $1 and it is easy to eat and walk with this pizza in hand. Don't bother sitting down because it's pretty cramped inside. Put $1 in the man's hand who gave you the pizza. They even cut it in half and gave us an extra plate because I only bought one to share with a friend (not realizing it was only $1).

I don't care if anyone calls me crazy or if what I'm about to say is blasphemous but I'm going to say it anyways: G.O.A.T. of all pizzas in New York!

A slice of cheese pizza cost $1 AND it tasted the best out of all the cheese pizzas I've had in New York. How could a pizza that cost $1 taste so damn bomb? This $1 pizza slice trashes all the pizza slices I've ever had in California. I really wish I could be there in New York to have another slice but sadly I am back in California. It doesn't get any cheesier than the cheese pizza here. Even the crust part tasted great with the bread being so thin and crunchy.

There's a few seating in the back but you could stand up and eat in the restaurant as well. To all the visitors out there reading my review: make sure to eat at this place, you won't regret it I promise.

It's hard to beat pizza for a dollar a slice. Said cheese slice was big, tasty, hot, and fresh. I liked how the crust was a little bit thicker, even if that's not the overt New York way. I would have liked to see some more flavor in the dough on the crust, but this is a tough value to beat. Just a small place so I just grabbed my pizza and went, didn't spend any time inside. Quite fresh for a midnight pizza run.
The music is so loud and disturbs everyone living near them. And they won't turn it off. Very annoying people . And bad pizza

Lesbihonest here... ANY place that can serve up a solid slice of margherita for $1, even in the ever expensive Manhattan, deserves five stars.

Please note about 2 Bros:
1. Only margherita slices are $1; all others go up to $2.50.
2. It's a grab & go place but there is limited seating in back.
3. Is it just me or I didn't see parmesan, but all the other spices seem to be covered?!

Whatevs. Pizza still a steal at $1!!

What can I say. $1 pizza . It is what it is .
Can't complain about the price.
But it doesn't have enough cheese I think.
Also always packed so good luck setting.
Great for the hangover nights.

Love that this place kind of mimic the Asian night market table and tools so if you have been to Asia and now miss it, you can get some of the experience here!

My gf and I walked in around 7-8pm on a Saturday and waited maybe 5 min for the table. We already looked at the menu while waiting so we knew exactly what we wanted and of course had to go for the 牛肉面（beef noodle soup). Order came pretty quick and not sure if we were hungry or what but finished it within 10 min. Noodles were bouncy but I think the meat could be a little more tender. Didn't melt in my mouth or anything like I would expect but the broth is very rich and hits the spot on a cold day.

Service is great - fast Even when they're busy. Great location and honestly just a good spot to start your night!

886 has been a great surprise. I was very skeptical since those with a hype and in st Marks can be to "americanized" but very surprised that the food was actually very good!!!
This place is realy small with about 10 tables in the dining room. Lights are blue neon so the place is quite dark.
The rest of the decor simulates any night market street food vendor tables you find in Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia... platic colored stool and metallic tables. Utensils and plates as well.
We went for anlunch and glad that they offered lunch specials. Two combinations both at $25 which includes two appetizers, one main and one drink.
We went for one lunch special (great deal) ordering fried tofu, chicken popcorn and loofah with clams.
The fried food was actually amazing. Tofu super crunchy on the outside and soft in the inside, same as chicken, crunch out and juicy in!
Also we had 3 cups chicken and the lobaben (rice with minced meat). Both were actually delicious and cooked Taiwanese style.
Service good and friendly.
4 stars only because clams should have been more fresh.

Will def come back tho!

It's obvious this place is extremely racist.

The staff was comprised of two white women and one Asian man. The restaurant was full of Asians except myself and my two friends (who were white Hispanic men ). After ordering our food, we were asked  while eating our meal if we were "finished" and "wanted the rest to go." Mind you, I had to swallow my food to answer the awkward Asain waiter, who then proceeded to "toss" my check on the table with the drink we ordered while we were eating. His behavior and gestures were noticeably angry and disturbing, and I felt totally embarrassed and ashamed.

It dont matter if the food is good or bad, that kind of racist behavior is unexceptable. Notice to the owner and staff, if you don't want anybody but Asians eating in your establishment, you should make it private so you don't have to rush Spanish people out.

I'll spend my money somewhere where im treated with dignity and respect. Thank you and good luck!!!!

My friend took me here because he said the food was really good. There was no wait when we got there. The vibe feels like you're in a night market. The restaurant is covered in this blue hue from the neon lights and blue walls.

Honey glazed popcorn chicken - you have to get this! The popcorn chicken is crispy on the outside and super juicy on the inside. The honey glaze adds a nice sweetness to the savory spices.

Beef noodle soup - I expected a little more but the broth felt bland. The beef was tender and flavorful but the noodles were overcooked.

I really enjoyed my visit to 886, which has been on my list for a while! The Notorious TFC was a standout dish. The fried chicken was very juicy and generously sized. The slaw in the sandwich had a really refreshing slaw. The beef noodle soup was pretty good, although I think the broth was a bit too thick. The service was fast and I liked that the restaurant had a lot of cute Taiwanese decor. I would like to come back to try their drinks, which sound really good.

用台灣當地的標準評美國的台式料理會不會不合理?

Well, even if not, for all the hype I've heard about 886, I was expecting a real treat when I finally stopped by for dinner with some friends last week. Unfortunately, it seems that their name (886 is the dialing code for Taiwan) is their most authentic feature. It seems they do a good job of selling a very Americanised version of Taiwanese food, which is... I suppose how they market themselves? But also rather disappointing.

We started with the lo ba beng 滷肉飯 - not a great start. The flavour of the sauce was not really authentic - overly sweet (?!) and kind of watery/thin. The sauce kind of just seeped through all of the rice and made it more like a 燉飯 risotto-like texture throughout. There was way too much pickled veggies 酸菜whose flavour was too strong, overpowering the balance between the rice and the pork. Finally, the runny soft boiled egg was interesting but also kind of dissonant, lu rou fan is almost always canonically served with braised soy eggs 滷蛋。

I guess to be fair, in an absolute sense the dish was not bad, but as noted above, it really just felt like someone tried to force lu rou fan into an Asian fusion setting. 而且這樣還要 $14？有夠誇張的

We also had the scallion pancake beef wrap 牛肉捲餅. The beef and pancake were tasty, but I couldn't focus on anything other than the random mayo that they added. I get that the 'szedaddy' mayo is a thing they're trying to do, but not only does it screams inauthenticity, it is a really odd flavour combo with the lighter flavours of the stewed beef and the savoury scallion pancake wrapper. Not a fan of this either. 我搜尋也搜尋了，"牛肉捲餅 美乃滋" 只有在墨西哥料理的食譜才找得到，非常不道地

Finally, we had the beef noodle soup. The noodles were nice - generally well-cooked at a nice degree of chewiness - and the beef bites were not bad - a little too hard for my taste but overall good flavour. The broth I did find to be a little lacking; it was much thicker and saltier than beef noodle soup normally is, and it really weighed down the overall flavour profile of the dish.

The environment is a bit disconcerting in my opinion - lighting was really strong as you can tell by the photos - and the layout makes it a bit loud as the sound echoes around the relatively small space very easily. The service was really good though, the servers were very attentive and we got our food in no time after ordering.

Overall, an acceptable but definitely inauthentic experience, and definitely much more expensive than it deserved.  I'd say save your money for cheaper and better Taiwanese food elsewhere in the city.

Such a trendy, pub-like place that serves up amazing Taiwanese classics! I was pleasantly surprised when I visited, and can't believe I had never heard of this place before. The atmosphere reminded me of a clubby indoor version of night markets in Asia!

Beef noodle soup 4/5: Noodles were nice and chewy and delicious, hearty broth!

Popcorn chicken: 4/5 tastes pretty similar to what you would get if you ordered this in Taiwan. The chicken was super crunchy and had a kick to it. The honey glaze was also a nice twist to add to it.

Seaweed fries: 3/5 Yummy, but nothing crazy. Classic crinkle cut fries served with garlic aioli and topped with furikake (the seaweed).

Overall, great place to grab cheap and delicious with friends! Would definitely come back to try some other dishes.

Wanted to like this place but was disappointed by the portion sizes. So small. See photo for hand comparison. Everything was just fine. Maybe would've been 4 stars if bigger portions but nothing really stood out. The egg was a perfect soft boil though. Ambience is nice, searing feels like a genuine lowkey restaurant in Taiwan and lights are fun.

Really great effort at popularizing Taiwanese dishes in NYC - the drink menu alone is worth visiting for. There's a fish bowl challenge that I personally did not partake in but looked fun. I think it was drink a fishbowl with 2 people in 30 seconds or something crazy like that.

The food is pretty decent especially the basics! The honey glazed popcorn chicken is welll seasoned and has a kick to it through out. The sesame noodles were surprisingly a favorite of mine with a cold refreshing peanut sauce and thinly sliced egg and cucumber. The hakka stir fry was a bit salty for me but not bad flavor at all.

It gets a little noisy but overall a great vibe for a dinner or for drinks!

Hip Taiwanese restaurant tucked away in St Marks with great food and great service. Met up with a friend for dinner on a weekday and it was very easy to get a table.

The menu consists of classic Taiwanese dishes/street food but with a unique twist. Highlights for me were the popcorn chicken (I loved the crispy basil and the honey glaze) and the sesame noodles (ultimate comfort food).

Service was great - the waiters were attentive (I dropped my chopsticks and before I could even pick them up, I was offered a new pair!) and both the owner and the chef individually stopped by to ask how the food was.

I recently went to 886 with a colleague for lunch after wanting to try this spot for years and was so glad that I finally made an excuse to go.

886 is a fab little spot over by the East Village that serves up Taiwanese classics like lo ba beng, three-cup chicken and so much more. As a Taiwanese American, I've always been on the hunt for tastes of home cooking so finally visiting this place was exciting to taste familiar dishes with a modern and fresh take.

They have this great lunch menu where you can get a few items for a proper meal. I loved their popcorn chicken and lo ba beng. I really want to come back for dinner and have a proper taste of all their main entrees. The portion sizes are solid, the menu is expansive, and the taste is on point.

Special shout out to their fantastic customer service, how fast they are getting their food out to you, and how their overall ambiance just adds an incredibly fun vibe to a solid experience.

Hyped to come back soon. My only regret is that I slept on this place for so long, 13/10.

Great no frills type Taiwanese restaurant in St. Marks. Just basic tables, good music, and a good time.

Staff was very friendly and explained a few of the dishes that were personally new to me.

The railroad layout of the restaurant did mean that sound carries. If someone is loud, you will hear them and think the place is loud. It is not a quiet restaurant by any means.

The back of the restaurant needs a little bit of an aesthetic facelift if you ask me. Bathroom in the way way back is nice though.

We ordered the following:

Chicken thigh sandwich - good flavor, but too many toppings that more than offset the flavor of the chicken. Wish the inside of the chicken thigh was a tad more cooked
Fly's head - very good and very different. Amazing flavor and probably my favorite thing
Scallion pancake beef burrito - unique and very tasty. Highly recommend ordering
Pork fried rice - ample amount of meat and fried egg. Tasty, but nothing that is tremendously unique

Would definitely return for a casual dinner!

886 is what I would describe as a modern Taiwanese restaurant with creative twists on Taiwanese classics. The vibe is pretty casual and the entire restaurant is bathed in this blue hue. I think the restaurant tries to resemble a Taiwanese night market, small stools and all, and while I think it's pretty cool, I can't deny that it's not the most comfortable of seating arrangements.

Onto the food, we shared the Taiwanese Fried Chicken ("TFC"), Popcorn Chicken, and Hakka Stir Fry. Everything was well executed and bonus points are given for the TFC being the size of my face. Portion sizes are generous and prices are very fair for the area.

Also, shoutout to our server for being attentive and giving great recommendations. Think this is fun spot to grab some bites and hang out in the East Village.

Came here late on a Saturday night, as 886 has been on my radar for a long time now due to the chicken sandwich.

It wasn't super busy when we arrived - plenty of open tables, but we were seated all the way in the back right next to the restroom.

Outside of the chicken sandwich, we didn't know what to get so looked up on yelp and thought the Taiwanese sausage fried rice looked really good - unfortunately, they must have recently changed it up a bit from the more recent pictures we had seen, because the chunks of sausage were very small (we were hoping for the larger chunks shown in the other pictures).

We ordered drinks, but only one was brought out. We had to ask again, but it took a while since our waitress was not really checking in on us.

The Notorious TFC was a glorious sandwich though, so I would probably return just for that.

A very photogenic restaurant in East Village with neon lights and taiwanese street style set up. It reminded me so much good memories back in the days in Taiwan. However, if you are looking for authentic taiwanese food, you would certainly get disappointed. I would rate it as a fusionized / Americanized taiwanese cuisine. FYI, 886 is the regional code of Taiwan.

＊ Lo Ba Beng滷肉飯
Mysterious taste...totally not what I expected from a taiwanese braised pork rice. Cilantro won't be added in a real one at Taiwan local food stall. There was also too much pickled mustard green which made the entire rice too sour. I like the sweetened soy ramen egg tho (yet a real lo ba beng usually uses braised eggs). A disappointing signature dish I would say.

＊ Honey Glazed Popcorn Chicken 蜂蜜鹽酥雞
VIP dish of the day. Actually nobody dips honey sauce on a popcorn chicken in Taiwan lol so this tasted more like a Korean style fried chicken. The outer coat was crispy, sweet and salty, while the meat inside remained tender.

＊ Beef Noodle Soup 牛肉麵
Love the noodle texture! Quite similar to the beef noodles I could have in Taiwan. The beef was served in thick slices but it wasn't tender enough. Would be better if it was slow-cooked. The soup was mediocre with saturated beef red sauce.

My Recommendations:
Honey Glazed Popcorn Chicken, Beef Noodle Soup

Worth Returning ? Probably no

886 has been on my list for ages after seeing Eric Sze's Munchies videos, and I'm so glad I finally checked it out. Managed to get a table walking in on a Saturday without a wait -might've been cause of the rain though.

The vibe is a mix of a Asian street and very neon pop - reminiscent of Taiwanese night markets. The food, while comprised of traditional elements, also had some fun playful twists. They were all pretty good though! What we got:

1. Pea shoots: my go to veg order - good but nothing different
2. Fly's head: umami, lots of black bean, perfect with rice
3. Sesame noods: this was so fire - springy Al dente noods, sesame paste nom. Nothing different but is it just me or are their noodles springier?
4. Beef scallion pancake: did not expect this to be as good as it was but this was also bomb - the filling with the sauce was so good
5. Honey chicken: fried chicken with 5 spice honey - I mean, how can this be bad

Overall, 886 is pretty . Casual Taiwanese food with some minor twists but all still great. Not your traditional joint but hey, it's fun and the food is still good.

Kinda just wish that they had dessert options - not sure if they have any since we weren't offered dessert and didn't see a table with it. Honestly would still come back- total comfort food feels
Would recommend a different spot. The food was good but expensive for little quantities. The service was slow too. Good food, but just not worth the cost. Lot of better options in St Marks

A cute, trendy and popular taiwanese restaurant in st marks with great service! I came here with my sister on a Sunday evening around 7:45pm without a reservation, and we were able to snag a table outside.
There's plenty of menu options for both food and drink. We tried their sesame noodles and beef noodle soup. For drinks we got hey song sarsaparilla (tastes like a mix of cola and root beer) and guava juice. As taiwanese girls, we agreed that our dishes were pretty good and overall tasted pretty authentic though with a slight modern twist. Next time, I definitely want to try their alcoholic drinks since they look really fun!
I'd recommend this restaurant for any time of the day.

Clubby atmosphere that's a great stop for drinks and snacks. We ordered:

grass jelly sake ($23) - 3/5. This came in a small carafe and was refreshing but a bit too sweet. I would've liked more alcohol, less syrup. But it was nice to get grass jelly at the bottom of my drink!

Honey glazed popcorn chicken ($13) - 4/5. I don't think this dish needs the glaze at all, which is too unctuous and sweet. The chicken itself is fried to perfection, though it comes in huge pieces. If it was smaller, it would make it more snackable.

Pickled cucumber salad ($8) - 4/5. Once again, the cucumbers in this were huge, almost meaty. I think the pickle flavor was perfect, though having the cucumbers so big meant you got punched with vinegar when you bit into one.

Hakka stir fry ($15) - 2/5. This is a pretty average stir fry. The sauce was a bit too salty, but there was a good mix of bean curd, meat, and veggies.

~ Lo Ba Beng (2.5/5) ~
Totally not what I expected. It's not authentic Taiwanese lo ba beng. The pork are too finely minced, and when combined with the sauce there are no texture whatsoever. The mix with sauerkraut is what I personally think unnecessary.

~ Honey Glazed Popcorn Chicken (4/5) ~
This rating is based entirely on the dish itself and not on authenticity. Because this is definitely not authentic Taiwanese fried chicken. But the chicken is fried to perfection, very crispy skin, very juicy center. The honey glaze is very nice, and not too sweet. Cant really taste the Thai basil leaves tho, I guess it's overpowered by the honey glaze. If they loose the honey glaze and add more Thai basil, then it could be an authentic dish.

Will I be back? Perhaps not (or maybe, if I feel like having some honey fried chicken!)
It's a matter of personal taste. I like traditional Taiwan food, and this is not. If you are a foreigner, it's definitively worth checking it out, but just don't expect it to be authentic. And that fried chicken is really good!!!

I actually went on a weekday when they just opened. Really love the decor of the shop. But what I really love is their beef noodle soup and it totally lives up to its hype. The soup was so flavorful, it's not overwhelmingly spicy, just a bit of a kick and you can taste anything. I almost drank the entire bowl. The beef is so tender yet so flavorful and not mush. You'd be surprised at how many beef noodle places can actually screw up on the beef, either too hard or too mushy, 886 gets it just right. It's an expensive bowl, I can probably get 3 or 4 bowls of decent noodles in Taiwan, but hands down the best bowl I've had stateside.

A must try if you're on St Marks!! I've gone for lunch multiple times

The chicken sandwich is super filling and very worth the price. The chicken is perfectly crispy and definitely something you can split with someone

Their service is prompt and the vibe looks like it would be fun at dinner time too!!

My friends and I decided to try this place because we saw it on social media and it lived up to the hype!

Expect a short wait if it's the dinner rush time. I thought the sausage fried rice alone could've been a whole meal but we also got to try the fried chicken poppers and the bulgogi (a table favorite).

I recommend the table split the larger format drink options. We got two of the lychee drinks for the table to share.

Don't expect a super fancy date night vibe. It's a trendy spot to meet up with a couple of friends.

The food here is soo yummy. My favorites are the lo ba beng (filling rice bowl) and the scallion pancake beef wraps.

The interior is neon-lit and super chic. Great place for a quick bite. Fast and friendly service.

I finally got to try this place after forever. For a group of 2, we were able to get seated within 10 mins. The chairs and tables reminds of me Chinese "da pai dong" or Hawkers; Metal table with plastic chairs with no backing. The service was attentive and the food came out fast.

We got the Honey Popcorn chicken, Peashoot with tofu skin, Lo Ba Beng and Seaweed fries. The popcorn chicken was my favorite! It was juicy on the inside and crispy on the outside. The peashoot quality was fresh, the fries were crispy and the Lo Ba Beng was flavorful. When I come back, I would definitely get the popcorn chicken again and try their other dishes and apps.

This is a relatively small size restaurant, get ls packed fast, and most of the time there's a long line. If you plan to visit, show up early. There's no clear big sign of the restaurant, you probably need to locate it using the building number.

Food wise I found it to be decent. We pretty much ordered all the items from the menu. My favorite was the three cup chicken and scallions pancakes beef wrap. Other items were not bad either.

I loved the Taiwanese beer. To me they tasted much better than US beers. I tried two flavors, both were excellent.

Amazing food for a pretty good price; good for small groups, no more than 4, ideal for 2. Service was speedy and the food came out only a few minutes after ordering. Seats are a little uncomfortable after a while, but overall good for an hour-long meal.

Honey Glazed Popcorn Chicken - Perfectly fried chicken, large enough for 2-3 bites each. They're so juicy and tender that some of them just fall apart in your chopsticks. For $12, a pretty sweet deal for a hardy helping. Sauce is sweet and somewhat spicy as well -- delicious.

Fly's Head - Loaded with scallions, this pork is flavorful, but subtle compared to the flavor from the popcorn chicken. Solid meal, pretty safe choice if you're not looking for something very spicy.

Value: 5/5
Quality: 5/5
Quantity: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Atmosphere: 3/5

A unique Taiwanese restaurant in the NYU area! For appetizers, we got the pickled cucumber salad that was refreshing and had a good balance of acidity and sweetness. I appreciated the large cuts of cucumber that was pickled nicely. The oyster pancake was interesting--a slightly chewy rather than doughy texture to the pancake and had a spicy keychupy sauce spooned across. It was a bit too spicy for my liking but balanced well with the cucumber salad! We also got the three-cup chicken that was served in a hot bowl. The dish itself was super flavorful and moist, and the aromas of basil deepened the flavors of the spices in the chicken. Same with the Sausage Fried Rice--couldn't believe how much flavor was packed in it. It was slightly oily, but delicious nonetheless.

Overall, I definitely recommend coming here and trying the three-cup chicken and fried rice!

The service was great, everything came incredibly fast, and our server was really nice and accommodating.

The guava soju carafe was really sweet, I would say it's on the stronger end for alcohol taste.

I also ordered the three cup chicken with koshikihari rice, which was fantastic! The flavor was a mix of sweet and savory and it comes on a portable stove. It could definitely feed two people. The koshikihari rice was high quality.

I also got the karaage/popcorn chicken which was super crunch and delicious.

I recommend ordering the apple sidra and mixing with the guava soju (or drinking alone, it's delicious).

As for ambiance and vibe of the restaurant, I went on a Friday evening around 11 and it still had enough space in the venue to be comfortable. Some restaurants pack their patrons in like sardines, but here I was comfortable enough to eat in peace. Great for pictures.

886 has been on my list for a while. Most of the dishes are authentic and definitely brings that Taiwanese flavor. Some dishes are more Americanized.

Service is quick. Very nice staff! Go when it's open , otherwise it gets crowded fast.

This is by no means a traditional Taiwanese place, and even with the expectation that this was a hip fusion place, I was still disappointed. The inside is small but looks pretty cool, and the service was fine nothing outstanding or terrible. The food is what really took it down for me. The dishes are all pretty small and not worth the price in my opinion. I tried the scallion pancake beef wrap which looked so delicious, and the individual components of it were really good. The scallion pancake was crispy and the beef was tender, but it was overloaded with spicy mayo, which completely ruined the flavor. Had there been no spicy mayo and just the regular hoisin sauce it would've been so much better. I also tried the lo ba beng (a version of traditional taiwanese lu rou fan) and it was mediocre. The flavors were ok, a little bit too salty for my taste, but the rice was just super wet and not the best texture. The one thing that I actually did really enjoy was the popcorn chicken. It was a good salt level and super crispy and I love fried basil

Great food, it's improved a lot since the last time I was here. We also got the popcorn chicken, three cup chicken, and sesame noodles. The scallion pancake with beef and Taiwanese sausage fried rice were my favorites. The indoor space is a little crowded and not great for big groups so we sat outside. Also ordered sake bombs with flavored beer and they were delicious. Food is just slightly salty but good for just a casual hangout.

I would rate this spot 3.5 but rounded it up. I have heard good reviews about this spot. Food was decent but I don't think it was spectacular. None of the dishes really stood out to me. Service and interior were good.

I'm glad I checked it out but I don't see myself returning.

What a gem in the St. Marks area. First timer in this area and met up with my cousins. This street is booming with different eats.

We sat outside of the enclosed area as the restaurant was packed. We ordered several things off of the menu. Really all your taiwanese favorites crammed into a small menu. We had the traditional beef noodle soup which was pretty tasty while the beef was super tender and the noodles were fresh with a bounce to the chew. Another item we ordered was the Chinese sausage fried rice which was pretty good as well. Sweet sausage cooked perfectly with the fried rice. We had also ordered the popcorn chicken which had a honey glaze to it. Chicken was well prepped with a slight crunch, I can do without the glaze.

They had several drink options and I saw they had a fruit version of the Taiwan beer. There are several flavors that I forgot but we opted for the Lychee flavor and Mango. Lychee is a bit on the sweeter side and the Mango is actually just right.

We loved the place and will be back to try all the other options. Taiwanese food fusioned in a hip joint in St. Marks. Go try it out!

It's been hard to find my replacement eats for Taiwanese food. The decor definitely reminds me of the the night markets in Taipei!

Ended up doing the "bad idea" bowl with my mate and... yes it was a bad idea. The night definitely went sideways HOWEVER. BEFORE it did:

1/ Oyster Omelette - not quite there and needs a bit more oysters in it!
2/ Lo Ba Beng - Needs yellow pickles!
3/ Taiwanese Sausage Fried Rice - must get!!
4/ Loofah and Clams

I'll definitely be back when I need a fix ;)

I tried the beef scallion pancake wrap, lo ba beng, and Taiwanese sausage fried rice for take out. Pick up only took around 20 minutes for my order to be ready which was really quick and easy.

The lo ba beng already comes with an egg, but I didn't know that so I added an additional egg which I didn't need. There were a lot of preserved vegetables which were delicious, the egg was jammy, and the meat was saucy and flavorful! This is some of the best braised pork rice I've had in the city, but in my opinion it's still not as fatty as the braised pork rice I've had in Taiwan (which I prefer it this way since it's adds more flavor and melts in your mouth).

The Taiwanese sausage fried rice was good and a pretty big portion! It came with lots of egg and sausage in every bite.

I also got the scallion beef pancake wraps which was my favorite. The sauce it came with was delicious, the beef wasn't too greasy, and it came with veggies inside that made it refreshing with added crunch. I'd definitely get this dish again!

We had such a good time here! The four of us came without a reso on Saturday night at 7:30 pm and were promptly seated.

Popcorn chicken with honey sauce - this was my favorite dish of the night. The chicken was lightly fried with a crispy and delicate breading. The chicken inside was super tender.

Lo Ba Beng - good, just what I was craving

Snow pea shoots - my favorite vegetable! really yummy and tender. Enjoyed the tofu in the dish, as well.

Fly's head - great, get some white rice to eat with it.

Scallion pancake roll with beef - super tasty

Overall, we are no strangers to Taiwanese food and found all the dishes were executed well!

If you're looking for authentic taiwanese food in the village, this is your place! We came right at opening and were seated immediately. Unfortunately they weren't seating anyone inside yet so we ended up sitting outside which was fine since the weather was nice. We ended up ordering a bunch of things to try and everything was perfectly seasoned and cooked! The drink menu was also pretty creative with many drinks to choose from. They didn't have the lychee soju available so we ended up getting the Guava which was pretty good as well. I'd definitely come back next time to try some of their other items on the menu!

One of the best restaurants on St Marks, hands down. It's worth the wait and the food is delicious.

This is a no frills establishment. You'll be sitting on a plastic stool at a simple table in the middle of a crowded restaurant - it's part of the appeal.

Order a fishbowl or some soju. We had plain soju with beer and it did the trick.

There are no menu items that aren't delicious. My absolute favorite thing on the menu.... The bacon and cabbage. Cabbage is general is such a underrated vegetable. It pairs perfectly with bacon and this dish is just a delight all around.

Arrive early, put your name on the list, and live out our best life with soju bombs and thoughtful food.
Everything I've tried at 886 has been delicious. It's a smaller restaurant so don't go with a large group. The service is very friendly. They play good music too.

Food was fresh and delicious! Cucumber pickled salad was refreshing (just like everyone said), fried chicken sandwich was beyond delicious, beef noodles and popcorn chicken were alright.

Super casual dining and totally worth the visit if you're in the neighborhood.

Best beef noodle soup I've had in NYC so far! I particularly like the noodles since they're QQ, which means they are really chewy. Soup is well seasoned and actually has vegetables and a good portion of scallions. They don't have extra noodles on the menu, but I asked for it and they delivered a portion for a whole village.
The sauce for the popcorn chicken is crack. It has some tang and spice to it that I can't quite describe. I might even buy that sauce separately?! The Minced meat pork rice aka lo ba beng was pretty good as well. Lots of sauce and meat. I like 886's version because they have the half cooked egg like in ramen. Fully cooked tea eggs just aren't the same.
I don't remember the pepper steak being a Taiwanese dish, but it was good. The sacha bbq sauce really goes well with the beef and pairs with a bowl of rice. Maybe I'll get the oyster pancakes next time, but the tables might not fit all the food. The furniture here definitely reminds you of a street stall at a night market.

Love 886! It can be hard to find Taiwanese food in the city but this is my go-to. I come here for the beef noodle soup (it has pickled veggies and the most tender beef) and the Taiwanese beer (best beer EVER). The grapefruit and lychee flavors are fire. Pricing is fair, dishes are under $20.

The restaurant has a night market feel. Plus, the location on St. Marks is pretty unbeatable!

Expect a line when you come - sometimes they open up a Yelp waitlist. I got here around 6:30 on a Friday and it wasn't too busy yet.

I was a worried that I would have to wait longer than I did for a table for 2 on a Saturday night! But don't let the line outside daunt you, they move fast! This is a great Taiwanese restaurant in a really fun spot!
