The service was not especially friendly probably because we don't speak Spanish. We ordered chicken and roast pork and they gave us chicken and steak with onions. We didn't want to argue so we just ate it and ordered some chicharrone on the side cause we really wanted some pork. We also got one relleno de papa, got two drinks, two rice puddings (which they had to open the lid and look at for some reason (which made me worried that they might be old)). Total cost $41.75 plus tip.  Seemed a bit pricey for what we got. All in all just OK. Not bad but not really that good either.

I ordered a platter of Roasted chickens from this place and I was really appalled by how they price gouged!!! Don't get me wrong the food here is simply delish... I eat here from time to time and the food is always good. But I was charged 75 dollars for a tray of  7 chickens n then charged more for them to cut it for me!! Disappointed that they are price gouging 6 months ago I ordered the same tray of roasted chickens and it was 40 dollars!!

This has been a favorite place of mine for over 20 years. The food is always great, the service is quick and the prices are well set.  The food is fresh, hot and well seasoned. True Puerto Rican food!

I was on my way to Three Way Restaurant and noticed the huge crowd. It wasn't even noon on a Saturday and this place was packed.  I checked my trusty Yelp app and decided to grab takeout from here instead.

We had:

Half rotisserie chicken (white meat) with yucca and red onions. No subs for white meat allowed. You literally get half - dark meat and all. The meat was not well seasoned, skin was not crispy and its overall appearance was pale. I've never seen such pale rotisserie in a Spanish restaurant.

Yucca was good.

Chicharones de pollo sin hueso (boneless chicken chunks). Came with yellow rice and peas as well as a side of red beans. The chicharones were superb. The rice not so much. Mushy texture and lacking flavor.  Beans were ok. Soupy, thicker than what I'm used to.

I also ordered a chicken empanada to nosh as I waiting for my order.

The woman who took my order spoke English and was very pleasant. She plated my empanada and brought it to me before putting my order together.

The empanada was great. Filled with tasty, shredded chicken and wrapped in a flaky crust. Perfect!  Ended up ordering an additional one to go.

Codfish cake - super greasy but tasty

There were a number of drinks on rotation but none are fresh. I noticed powered packets in baskets under the counter.

Take out is king here. There's a small counter with about 8 seats and I believe one or two tables.

There's also a lotto station for those who want to play their numbers.

Decent spot. Cheap enough. I got all of the afore mentioned items for $20.40

The draw here is the fare that is their namesake. Anything fried is superb. Everything else is just decent.

More 3.5 but rating 4 because the customer service is fantastic.

I'd definitely stop in again.
3.5 for sure. At night the food that was out all day can taste like plastic or rubbery. But the food is over all good. I will eat here again.

I stop here occasionally for lunch because of the cheap prices and delicious food.

If you are on Fordham and want authentic food this is definitely the place to go. I especially like their plantains with meat and cheese.

Avoid this place during peak hours because everyone and their mom heads here and there is no structure for a line and rather its a hungry crowd of people pushing to the front.

The staff are nice and will explain the menu in english if you have questions about the menu.
Great food excellent price and fast and friendly service. Highly recommend to anyone visiting or local. We love this place.

I was so looking forward to some good frituras. What a disappointment and waste of money. We didn't get everything we paid for and the drive back was just not worth the aggravation of traffic. The frituras were limp and very greasy and don't get me started on the TASTELESS pasteles. Will definitely never go back.

A almost extinct breed . This is a real cuchi frito spot . ( I def spelled that wrong)

Mofongo steak rice beans . Can't pronounce or spell any of it but I eat it all . Fried chicken is on point too . Def a recommendation for the area
Best Cuchifrito in town!!! The chicken was great. The rice and beans were like home and the morcia was to die for.
After today I am no longer going to go to this Cuchifrito Frito spot anymore. I ordered a pernil and look what I see.

The food is good but I just get fried pork chop w rice & beans.

Everything is fried. But still good . Very popular spot

"Parts Unknown" got me here. Anthony Bourdain's visit to the Bronx as an "exotic destination" turned up this gem, the Sine Qua Non of Latino cuisine.

No, it's not Cubano, or Mexicano - it's quintessential Puerto Rican cooking, and they do the heck out of it.

My initial ignorance of the cuisine led me to choose the eponymous "Cuchifritos" on my first visit...I did see them being dished out on "Parts Unknown," but it turns out (I learned later) on Anthony's on-camera plate was a load of Chicharrones. I got there and didn't know how to order it!

Chicharrones (per se) are not on the menu at 188 Cuchifritos, but they are in the window. Chicharrones are such a staple, they're assumed in Puerto Rican cuisine. Chicharrones defaults to mean deep-fried, un-breaded Pork Belly. The skin is a dream of crispiness. It's like an hallucination of uncured bacon in its ultimate state. Here,  It's beyond description delicious.

A variant - Chicharrones de Pollo  - is on the menu, and it's astonishing. A chicken lover's delight. Eat your heart out, Buffalo Wings!

The Cuchifritos, which I did experience, were plenty tasty, but I was disturbed later to discover they're tripe. Served with blood sausage, they were a little challenging for my palate. I'll grow into them, I'm sure.

No, it's all about the Chicharrones here for me.

And, the indescribably savory yellow rice, black beans, diverse and vibrant salad with pink pickled onions, and sublime Flan.

You gotta go here if you're a pig or chicken lover. This is the stuff!

The 4 Fordham Road stop is a block north and half a block east of the place.

GO.

Delicious puerto rican food. This is primarily a take-out place, since seating is VERY limited and crowded.
Menu is extensive and can be difficult to navigate if you don't speak spanish. When you enter, the walls are entirely covered with all sorts of dishes that you can order - it can be quite overwhelming.
I have heard from multiple people that their chicken and pork dishes are amazing.

So far, I/we have only tried a few items but liked: barbecue chicken, rice and beans, sweet plantains - these were the best, Tres leche is soooooooo good.

I did not like the Mofongo, but this was my first time trying it. It was too dry for me even with the gravy.

Will definitely go back here. Staff is friendly and helpful. Vegetarian options are limited to rice and beans, mofongo, and salads.

I grew up in Washington Heights where all the Cuchifrito places are now becoming extinct.  
I came here because Anthony Bourdaine did, and because it's fairly easy to get to off the 207 St. Exit off the Major Deegan, or cross the 207St. bridge from Manhattan.

You better be prepared for the Bronx Experience, LOL!  You got all types wandering through here, talking to themselves or complimenting your clothing, which to me means they want to steal it, I'm no fool. The poor Lotto Lady is in a small plexiglass bird cage for protection.  Mostly people are here for the super tasty latin food at very affordable prices.

Doesn't matter, that's the Bronx, and you are not coming here for the sparse decor, you're coming here for great tasting food and dirt cheap. I bought enough food for 6 people at just under 30 bucks with tax, and it was delicious:
2 Chickens, L Plate of Rice, L Beans, Plate of Yuca w Red Onions, YUM!  God Bless the Bronx.
Good prices!! Great food!  Staff kind. The place is always busy but I never have to wait long.  Love their Cuban sandwich!!
I live in Massachusetts since 1999 but I always make a special trip to the Bronx to eat at this Cuchifrito's it's the best !!!!
The best mofongo ever! Definitely authentic and delish. Would recommend to go and try it out.

The mofongo con chicharron de pollo sin hueso was delicious! I wish I would have purchased another one for breakfast for the next day. I also purchased 10 alcapurrias and those were delicious but a little salty. I would definitely come back here again when I can as this is the old school food I love!

This diner offers all of your favorite traditional and greasy latin staples. Many celebrities have eaten there, Anyhony Bourdain even did a segment on this place for one of his shows. The food is great, with my inly exception being the finger foods that are either hit or miss (pastellilos, empanadas, etc) they are often left on the counter for many hours and arent always fresh.

Obviously, cuchifritos means oil fat and lots of butter. I came here with my grandma and got some stuff to go. The yucca balls are really good. The quipes were tasty as well. My favorite part was the chinola juice, it wasn't tangy and overbearingly sweet. It tasted natural and refreshing (although I'm sure it's not natural) it was satisfying. I saw people enjoying a full meal while I was waiting for my order. It was full on a Saturday night at 6pm which also means, this place is probably the place to be. Next time, I'll try the pasteles and pernil with rice. You have to remember that places like these, aren't going to offer you five star service - it's a cuchifrito spot ! But the food is delicious and the ladies behind the counter were patient and helpful.
Really good and cheap food at this local cuchifritos!! I love their chicharron and their pernil !!  Very good snacks and tasty treats all for very cheap. Be prepared to speak Spanish

This is a Classic Cuchifrito spot.
Not much to see here, I mean if you've got it bad for some deep fried pork, empanadillas, pig foot soup, pollo al carbon & rice & beans, stop in and get your fill for under 10 bucks.
I would opt out of 'dining in' as there is heavy foot traffic and not much in the ways of ambiance.

Staff is quick and attentive, you are in and out in a few minutes.
The pernil (roast pork) is delicious... get extra napkins because it is greasy... as is the nature of Cuchifritos.

Buen Provecho.

I'm not Dominican but this food is crate  here are some pictures so yah can see how it is . the food is grate, there is a variety of food and I was crazy looking at it . So I decided to buy what ever look delicious to me . and I don't regret it. The food is so good . THE ONLY BAD THING IS THAT THEY DON'T DO DELIVERY.

I highly recommend this place. Food is always fresh. I normally buy the combo dishes. Very good and well worth it. The only difference w/ other  locations that sell the combo is the 2 liter soda bottle. They don't include the soda.

Best Bang for a buck .

Get it !

I've had worse pizza for way more money but I've also have had better hence the 4 out of 5 review . The only problem I have is at one dollar I get a slice almost every day !
No longer exists- this location is permanently closed. There is NO 2 bros pizza.. dont drive there

Let me just say this, I use to frequent this location regularly because I'm a driver and this was my quick go-to for lunch. I remember the young guy that was there before the guy you have in there running the place now. He was quick professional and for some reason the pizza was DELICIOUS.
Now the pizza taste like there's no seasoning in the sauce the slices are ALWAYS BURNT or the lil Dominican guy in the front is ALWAYS counting money when I come in. It never fails...I walk in..he's counting money..order slice.. counting money..pays for slice..STILL COUNTING MONEY! Whoever's making the pizza tell them to go back to the OLD RECIPE!!!! I get it..it's a DOLLAR pizza..but don't get us use to GOOD dollar pizza, to now give us shitty DOLLAR pizza!
2bros pizza is known for their quality. That's what I expect every single time! Fordham location fell off!

They don't use gloves which is very unsanitary and honestly disgusting. They touch other surfaces and still make the pizza with their dirty hands, we get it the pizza is $1.50 but at least make it im a clean way

They closed a cheap pizza place down the street on Webster Avenue just around the time they opened this one & I consider this to be an upgrade.
If you want quality, walk another 10 minutes & you'll find several better options on & around Arthur Avenue.  But for .99 a slice, how much can you complain?  Super convenient when you're just getting off the train - breathe out the stink of the subway & step inside for a lice.  Best when you go during a peak time & the pizzas are fresh out of the oven.  Otherwise, you might be dealing with a lower quality product.  Just blot off the grease & try not to burn the roof of your mouth.

The pizza is decent and filling. What do you expect for a $1 though. They don't use gloves however to prepare the pizza which I think is unsanitary and honestly disgusting. I had to find a new pizza place because of that and their B rating from the department of heath.
Really great pizza for a great value! It's the best dollar slice pizza around and I've tried so many. Lines get pretty long but they move quickly. Small store so not much seating.
A great little deli just a block from the local Essen clinic. They serve dollar coffee that's legit. The owner is a likable guy.
The morning crew is okay, but the three times I went in the evening they always tried to overcharge. Very dishonest employees!

Over priced and make sure you check the dates on the drinks
The place just opened how are the drinks out dated allready
Amazing service, delicious food (had the half pastrami and matzoh ball soup)! We were even given some blue and white cookies on the house. Hands down, the best nyc restaurant.

I stopped by and got a to go order of their 10. Royal 2nd Ave triple decker sandwich for $35.  It was relatively busy with quite a few people waiting for a table.  I wasn't sure where to order, but eventually a butcher asked if I was being helped and I gave him my order. In return, he gave me several scraps of Pastrami to try while I waited, which were very good.  I didn't wait too terribly long to get my food.

It came with a bunch of their meats on it, but did not come with chopped liver or any other salads.

I was surprised it came with pickles, after seeing everyone on here complain they they nickle and dime you for them.  It also came with nice deli mustard and thousand island dressing for those who need those.

The sandwich itself was very good. It's basically the meat mountain that Arby's offers, but with deli meats.  I think there was flavors being drowned out by the most power meats.  I would go with something simpler next time.  The meat and bread overall was good, but perhaps I agree with the others that it was a lot of money for the amount provided.  I'd still come back to try maybe the #3.

The 2nd Ave Deli is definitely on my top-10 list of eateries at NYC. Whenever I visit NYC I come here most of the time, and I usually arrive very hungry.

The pastrami sandwiches are outstanding, but OMG the pickles and the slaw are what made me fall in love with the place.

The service isn't overwhelming, but is refreshingly un-intrusive and prompt. My most recent visit was this week and the food was as good as ever.

The service was exceptional. Our party was well taken care of, the food was delicious and clearly made fresh in house (including their Russian dressing). I recommend their chocolate soda after your meal.

It's a little pricey. If you're looking for a grab and go bodega deli this isn't it but their sandwiches rival Katz.

The corned beef and sauerkraut was tender and tasty.  I also had a few bites of my friend's baked potato knish.  It was moist and not too heavy.  The fresh cut French fries were nicely crispy.  My friend enjoyed the roasted 1/2 chicken with broccoli.  The complimentary slaw, pickles and black & white cookies (though they were blue & white) were all great.  I particularly liked the coleslaw because it was vinegar based and very fresh.  The server was a little impatient, but everything came out quickly and was fresh.

2nd Ave Deli never disappoints.  Sure, the sandwiches are a little pricey, but sooooo worth it.  I always order the pastrami and it is always served to perfection.  Their pastrami sandwich is iconic.  Everything else (which is also great) is a bonus.  Service was terrific.  We were seated immediately and our server was attentive and wonderful.  

What can I say?  I will always make a trip tp 2nd Avenue Deli due to its consistency and great food.

I had the challah French toast and a side potato pancake with apple sauce. All meals also come with coleslaw, pickles, a cookie, and a chocolate soda. The food was all decent, but nothing too remarkable. The staff is very friendly. My meal came out to about $33, which was a bit more expensive than I would've liked.

A classic old school Jewish Deli to order your Pastrami sandwich on Rye. Don't except the price to be cheaper but you can see the amount of pastrami in the sandwich. They'll serve it with house mustard along with some pickles the most classic way.
Have tried many Deli's and restaurants in many states. Hands down best hot pastrami ever!
Awesome place - the pastrami sandwich and chocolate babka were excellent! Highly recommend - quick service and great staff!

I came with a friend for dinner on a weekday at 7pm, but we were told that while the place closes at 8, the kitchen closes at 7! They kindly seated us anyway and we already knew what we were ordering, but just a heads-up that this isn't a late-night establishment like some other delis in the city.

My friend and I ordered one pastrami sandwich to share, since we knew it was pretty big with a ton of meat (plus, they're on the pricy size for a sandwich). We initially planned to add cole slaw on it for an extra charge, but our server was nice enough to let us know that it came with complimentary cole slaw on the side and not take us for suckers.

The side cole slaw was a pretty hefty portion and we ended up taking some home - it's not as mayonnaise-y as most cole slaw but more sour like sauerkraut. It also came with mustard and two whole pickles. The sandwich itself wasn't quite as big as I expected, but it was indeed piled with meat and still left me satisfied. The pastrami was sliced thin more like roast beef; I think I prefer the thicker brisket-like pastrami I had at another place, but that may be personal preference and the meat was still great quality. The bread was also very nice and soft, not dry at all.

To finish the meal, we were given two complimentary little cups of chocolate soda which were a fun and sweet way to end the meal! Overall, good but not extraordinary food, but the little free things make it more worth than it might first appear. I wouldn't mind coming back to try the matzoh ball soup (and to avoid the crowd at Katz).

Holy cow, I love this place! When I visit NYC, one of my priorities is to grab a corned beef on rye. I can get a good sandwich in RI, but it's take-out only without a full deli experience.
The 2nd Ave Deli gives the full experience I'm looking for without the tourist crowd at Katz's (though if I'm honest the decor at the tables here is perhaps working a bit too hard to make sure I know that I'm in the 2nd. Ave. Deli (cue the placemats, private label on the mustard, and the dividers between the narrow hall and tables proclaiming where I'm sitting). Maybe that's because the deli counter is a bit further away and separated from the seating area than is common in most delis? Also, said seating area is a bit cleaner and more comfortable than most others (no complaints about that last fact from me).

I loved the big plate of pickles served without us having to ask - both half and full sour so I didn't have to choose just one! I also loved the way my matzoh ball soup was served: cooked carrots and (large) matzoh ball in the bowl, with a metal cup of soup in the middle. As the waiter brought over the bowl, he poured the soup over the carrots & the (I already mentioned, large) matzoh ball. Nu, so elegant! The matzoh ball was light and fluffy too, just the way I like them; no sinkers for me please. The carrots were NOT the soggy cooked-in-the-soup ones my Bubbe would have fed me either; these were cooked just right for balance with the yummy fluffy matzoh ball. This soup? I didn't even need to add salt!

The corned beef on rye was appropriately overstuffed. I heeded the warnings and didn't order lean or extra lean so it was juicy. And so tender. Fresh and sturdy rye bread too. The coleslaw was good: mayo based not vinegary like the appetizer taste.

After we ate, as we had the bill delivered we also had a shot glass-sized gift: An egg cream! I haven't had an egg cream in about 35 years - since my mother refused to make them after she stopped having those schpritz bottles of seltzer delivered to our house. It was the same seltzer & chocolate syrup drink I mostly refused as a kid because they were... weird. But like most things in New York delis, this place makes me happy because it reminds me every visit to family in my youth (but the visit is much more expensive now!).

The one disappointment was that they had no black and white cookies available at the counter. Despite this, still five stars!

I might get a lot of heat from the pastrami community, but this is better than Katz's.

Sat down to eat here and we ordered a matzo ball soup and pastrami sandwich on rye.  I haven't had too much matzo ball soup before, but I thought the noodles were good and the soup was perfect to counteract a cold day.  

The pastrami on rye is on a completely different level.  It's a bountiful portion (really two people can each take a half and get full).  The flavor of the pastrami was rich and incredibly satisfying on each bite.

Don't miss out, you need to eat here.

Classic NY Jewish deli. Been visiting all my life (nostalgic for the original location in the east village). After all these years, still one of my all-time favorites. Usually do 1/2 sandwich and soup. The matzoh ball soup is the best I've had. The broth is sooo flavorful, and the matzoh ball big and fluffy. The brisket (with a side of gravy) and corned beef (with mustard) are my go-to sandwiches. I find these meats superior to other places in Manhattan. (For pastrami, it's Katz's.. not kosher tho) Yes, it's pricey, but you get what you pay for, and the food they're serving up is top-notch jewish nosh. The service and staff are wonderful. Complementary pickles, health salad, and chocolate soda shot.. What's not to love?

Crossing off another New York Deli on my list, this is one of those delis you know, want to try, but never do. That has now changed, I have tried it. I got myself on a subway to Midtown, made the walk, and ate food here.

This is the food of my culture, so I take this pretty seriously. It also helps I am now back in the area where Kosher/Jewish delis are somewhat more abundant than where I used to live, where there was maybe one or two delis, or none at all.

Without further ado, here is what I thought.

The restaurant is clean, reminiscent of the Jewish delis from the first half of the twentieth century, particularly those right here in New York. The menu is also extensive, and when I found out they cure all their meats in house, I had to dive in. I got a matzo ball soup, a small sampling of pastrami, a side of kasha varnishkas, and for my sandwich, a club of corned beef, tongue, and soft salami.

First came the soup. The matzo ball soup is something that I feel is the backbone to any Jewish deli. A good one sets the meal up nicely; a poor one can set it back. Unfortunately, it is the latter. Overcooked noodles, and an undercooked matzo ball. The chicken broth is pleasant and smooth, but too many noodles sink to the bottom. The carrots in the soup at least add a nice touch.

With the soup comes the complementary pickles and coleslaw. Now they are two schools of thought to the coleslaw game, either it can be vinegar or mayo based. This restaurant chooses the former for its slaw. I am not a fan of this style; too runny and stringy for me. The pickles are too soft, no crunch to these briny cucumbers. They fall flat.

Then my sample of pastrami came out. I like a good pastrami, salty and soft, but not too stringy. This one was bone dry. Plenty of mustard will be needed to make this work. I was prepared for a mediocre experience, but then, with the next few dishes, my luck began to improve.

The sandwich came next, with the kasha. The corned beef just melts in your mouth, delicious flavor and feel. The tongue follows next, and it is a soft, chewy, melty flavor that works exquisitely. Lastly, the salami comes, and it rounds out the sandwich nicely with a cured flavor to balance things out. This time, the coleslaw given is mayo based, and this really helps give the sandwich a good zing. It also helps the sandwich is served with seedless rye, enabling it be more easily digested. I used mustard, but these meats do not need it. That is why it works.

Alternating between sandwich bites, I got some hit of the kasha. The kasha is okay, has good taste, and the bow tie pasta is cooked perfectly. It does go a bit overkill on the onion and onion powder, so I could not eat it all. However, after many years of not having a restaurant do it right, it is nice to have one that does. Maybe next time I will try the mushroom barley.

At the end of the meal, they give you a complementary shot of a New York egg cream. A nice way to end things and help move things along in your stomach just a little bit faster. Definitely do not pass this up.

After saving itself with a good sandwich, I would also say to not pass this restaurant up. Come to Murray Hill and enjoy a good sandwich from here. It is no Katz's, but I think you will appreciate this one for what it is.

The very best pastrami in New York, the one and only, 2nd Avenue Kosher Deli!

I dream of 2nd Avenue while I am in California. It is pretty much the only meat this 364-day vegetarian eats.

I got lean, but not extra lean, pastrami. Perfection! Humongous and very warm, with the best Ryebread and mustard.

I also got a round potato knish which was delicious and that I saved for later.

I don't think that their chicken matzoh ball soup is the best in the city. It's a little heavily salted. But it is still very good and the matzoh balls are lovely. I usually don't mess with the noodles with the soup is too filling.

This location is hurting now because a lot of workers haven't come back to offices, and they need more business. This is a New York institution. Do yourself a favor and take advantage of the fact that there are not huge lines now. You can do takeout or dine in.

Shout out to the awesome counter guys who were playing Mexican music while they worked. They can slice deli just like the old Jewish dudes who worked at the 2nd Avenue location. Super nice too.

Please keep Second Ave. in business so that I can come next time in New York! They are THE BEST.

I'd really want to give this 3.5 stars but i do feel everyone should go once. The ambiance is very old time diner so that was fun. Service was prompt but extreme curt.

The pastrami was definitely the star here. My daughter said it was even better than Katz's deli. The pickles and slaw were complementary and very tasty.

The lox was good. This place is quite pricey but definitely worth a one time trip.

I heard about this place after seeing videos and articles on Jewish delis prior to my trip. I came around 11:30am to pick up take out. Everyone was so kind and welcoming!

I ordered a half sandwich/soup combo. The soup and matzoh ball was very flavorful. The pastrami was well seasoned with a nice char. The sandwich came with condiments on the side for assembling. Fast service! order at the deli, pay at the register and pick up at the deli.

At here on 10/19/23 and ordered take out pastrami and chicken salad sandwiches. My husband and I sustained food poisoning. This is a valid reason to write a review, so others do not get sick. If the restaurant would like to contact me and refund this bill of $77 takeout (2 sandwiches and 1 soup), I will remove this review. For almost $80 for 2 sandwiches and soup, I should absolutely never, ever get sick.

They have lost my business. I have been here before and I liked that I could come by for a pastrami sandwich on occasion. I didn't expect to be called stupid as soon as I walked in asking if they accepted Apple Pay. I had just gotten off clinic and didn't have my wallet on me, so I asked if they accepted apply pay and was returned immediately with "that's a stupid thing to do, why don't you carry a wallet around?" Multiple times in various iterations, I was called stupid and ridiculed as I walked out the door. That type of aggressive behavior towards anyone is unacceptable and should not be encouraged.

Please reconsider giving them your business in lieu of the numerous businesses that will actually make you feel welcome and happy to have you nearby. As stupid as  solely having a phone on you may be, at least it can make a proper review.
The Pastrami sandwich and stuffed cabbage were fantastic! Definitely worth it for the price!

Still a favorite. People still very friendly, great customer service. Really 4.5 stars. Like many places there have been some changes maybe due to Covid. Quite a few places have increased prices. I don't think they increased prices but the serving sizes seem smaller than they used to be. The health salad, cole slaw with no mayo, still great. The corned beef and pastrami still very rich and tastes great but wish was still the old sized. But I get it costs, expenses cause limitations

I'm an NYC native and I finally went here. Definitely one of the best sandwiches I've had in my life, let alone a pastrami sandwich. Service is great. I went on a Saturday afternoon and the wait was 10 minutes. I wish I had pictures but the sandwich is gone.

Quintessential kosher Jewish deli in New York City that has lasted so many years for a reason.

We ordered a Pastrami on Rye, a Corned Beef on Rye, a mushroom omelet  a potato salad and Kasha Varnishkas for sides. Everything was flavorful and super fresh, if anything I would have preferred the meat to be cut thicker, but that's just my opinion.

Service was swift and with a smile.
It is pricey even for  the quality of the food.
The place keeps the smells and looks of always ...

Will keep coming back for more of that delicious pastrami.

Ordered the hot pastrami sandwich take out and gotta say it was solid. The r bread was robust yet soft. The beef was sliced very thinly. The spice is pronounced but not too overpowering. The smoke is there and the beefiness is there. I feel this is a text book good pastrami sandwich. Really enjoyed it and will recommend it.

4 stars - recommended.

Ps. I'm not giving up on thicker cut tho. I still think the texture with thicker cut is better. You got more beef texture rather than ham or bologna.

I've been going to 2nd Ave Deli since I was a kid (when it was really was on 2nd Ave.) and It would be  impossible to find a better Jewish or Kosher deli anywhere.
Some people like the much larger and more popular downtown Katz's Deli better that really is a tourist or suburbanite restaurant also the few remaining Jewish delis in the outer boroughs aren't nearly as good as 2nd Ave Deli.

Because they abide by strict Kashrut dietary laws you will not find any Rueben's or any dairy products (go to Katz's for that) but the adherence to
Judaic Kosher rules and restrictions work in favor of the deli. The sandwiches are not covered up by cheese and have to excellent by themselves - and they are.

Some people complain about the price of a sandwich - which with tax and tip will hit the $35 mark but it's really worth it.
The sandwiches are big and include cole slaw and pickles, beside the taste is superior to less expensive sandwiches which more than justifies the cost.
You are paying for a quality labor intensive product.
Try a Pastrami or Corned Beef here and then try eating a similar sandwich elsewhere and you will see the difference and it's huge.

The dining room is okay looking but could feel a little tight when busy  
and service is matter of fact but efficient.

Definitely check out the sides as well as the Matzoh Ball soup.

YUM...it was my first time eating Pastrami and it was delectable.  A true deli experience you won't want to miss.  My husband ordered the over stuffed corn beef and was truly "fat & happy".  We will be sure to eat here again....

The food continues to be good, but the ambience and set-up is below par.  When ordering take-out, the counter is very high and the staff behind it can barely be seen.  A lot of activity and noise are happening, and the order took too long.  A hold-over from the original, one has to pay before given the food.  Staff is slow and gruff, unfriendly and lacking in any type of charisma or concern for customers.

It survives on its decent food quality in spite of the especially high prices.  Of course, the overstuffed sandwiches make up for some of the mark-up.

We were glad to go, but left feeling it was an unpleasant experience and that the staff hasn't left the "Lower East Side"--which some might find charming, but as a native New Yorker, it was off-putting.
One of the best pastrami sandwiches I've ever had. This place has all of the cute NYC things you want. So so good.

Don't expect 5 star service.  Do expect some wonderful deli meat!

This place has larger portion sizes than other well known delis and isn't nearly as crowded but does the job well.  The portion sizes is also commensurate to their pricing as it's a bit pricier.  Cole slaw is also a bit more on the vinegar side

Great spot, would highly recommend!

I try to come here every trip to NYC. A bowl of matzo ball soup, pickles and 1/2 a tongue on rye sandwich with mustard always makes things better. The shot of chocolate soda they give you with your check makes the perfect end to a great meal.

We wanted to get nyc's iconic pastrami before we flew out....I doordashed this order and thought because it was $25 that it was a ginormous sandwich. It was not. I was shocked and relatively disappointed of the size and the meat stack. Perhaps buying in store is cheaper but $36 for a sandwich with no sides is insane. I thought maybe fries or something. The bread looked like standard sandwich size. I have a deli back home where the bread is jumbo and meat stack is high for $16. Insane.

Same as before. Excellent food. Fantastic  service. Everything huge

Tried some new items
Shared turkey sandwich with son. Had derma with gravy,  shared with sil. Great.

Older DaughtBen's. Fantastic chicken soup of course, but thought she could eat 3 latkes too (potato pancakes) :)

Wife And sil shared their specialty (pastrami of course). No Brainer- excellent

Younger daughter had kasha and chopped liver. I tasted the chopped liver. Best I've had

Service was great even though late in day.

2nd ave deli Now our favorite nyc kosher deli. Bye bye ben's.

Delicious cold cuts. Don't buy anything else! I just had a kasha knish,,, The kasha was hard like a rock. I looked art the bottom and it was BURNT,
Not edible ,,, went to the garbage.

Fabulous chicken soup.
Love the old fashioned ambiance.
One never knows who will show up:
While eating my pastrami sandwich,
in walks Gal Gadot.
No one made a scene. Just kept munching.

Said to be one of the top pastrami sandwiches in NYC. I had to stop here myself and check out out, well worth the trip. The slices of meat are cut perfectly thin and very very juicy. The bread comes room temperature and deli mustard on the side . It pairs perfectly with the with the saltiness of the meat. The sandwich and ice tea cost roughly $32, and it comes hot quick and fresh!

#tellemcraigsentyou

Pro Til - Bring CASH they do not take card or Apple Pay!
In no universe whatsoever does a quart of a basic soup and a few slices of bread need to cost $28. For that price you can get so many better meals in the local area. This is simply ridiculous.
Excellent kosher deli. They have everything you would expect, crowded dining area. Great service and host was very nice.
The service is always excellent, the meats melt in your mouth and the latkes are perfectly crispy. It's a classic New York deli for a reason.

The hot pastrami literally melted in my mouth. It was excellent. The apple strudel and chocolate babka were outstanding. I love this place. In the words of Neal Brennan, "If you're a restaurant that closes by 9 p.m. you're really just a lunch place." FYI - 2nd Ave Deli stops seating dine-in customers at 7 p.m. and closes at 8 p.m. What are you waiting for?! Get moving and get there early enough to enjoy their amazing food!

Call before you
go.  They state they close at 8pm on Sunday.  I drove down two hours from upstate to pick up family visiting from abroad.  They were craving Pastrami.  Arrived there at 7:20 pm and an older man at the register said we're closed.  Thank goodness he let me use the restroom.  As I was walking out he said come back tomorrow.  Thankfully we went to Ben Kosher's, made it before 8pm and they served us so no, we won't be going back today.
Best pastrami on rye in nyc! There I said it! Great matzo ball soup too. There's really nothing more to say.

Love trying all the NYC delis!

Hubby and I shared: matzo balls soup with noodles ($11.95), hot pastrami sandwich ($24.95), and a potato pancake ($7.50). We also received the complimentary coleslaw and pickles each.

Service was friendly and made us feel like we were regulars. Dining room was clean and service was fast.

They didn't ask how fatty we wanted our pastrami but I think we got the medium to lean version. Still it was good solid pastrami sandwich. The matzo ball soup was clear and well seasoned - definitely the Jewish penicillin it claims to be as I certainly felt great after having it! The potato pancake was very crispy outside and creamy with a very thick layer - definitely a thicker latke than I am used to but still great especially with the apple sauce to cut a bit of the grease. Coleslaw was vinegar based and perfect to cut the grease of the meal and the pickles were tangy.

Great neighborhood deli for sure!

As a regular at tenth street,where everything was good,l wanted the uptown location to be great. Sorry:at one visit the brisket could be not be identifiable as such;at another-and my last- visit,the pastrami was inedibly tough. And this from someone would have bent over backwards happily to see it succeed.

We tried this place and we all love everything we ordered here. Everybody is happy! I will recommend the Matzoh Ball Soup and Hot Pastrami Sandwich. We will definitely be back here again for our next trip. Highly recommended. All fresh and clean ingredients.

This place gets a 3 star only because the pastrami was fairly decent and the cabbage slaw served when you first sit down was pretty good as well. The service by our waiter sucked. He came to take our order and before we could finish he turned around and started taking someone else's order. Had to tap him on the shoulder and let him know I was still ordering he didn't even ask what we wanted to drink. We got a pastrami and a brisket sandwich and my husband specifically asked for juicy brisket however the sandwich was dryer than the Sahara you choked on it. Not only was the brisket extremely dry it was very bland. We left it on the table and the guy who cleared the table saw it and asked what was wrong we told him it was dry and his response was "yea sometimes that happens". Besides the shabby service and lackluster food this place is extremely overpriced we paid $5.50 for a 6oz glass of orange juice that tasted like Tropicana that went bad, $13.50 for 6 tiny pieces of franks in a blanket which was basically 1 hot dog cut into tiny pieces and wrapped it dough that was somehow burned on top but raw at the bottom. Definitely will not be back and would not recommend.
Great service, tasty food, generous portions. Took off 1 star because the stuffed derma wasn't our favorite and the prices were a bit $$$. Come between lunch and dinner time to avoid a crowd/wait.

I have been to 2nd Ave Deli many many times, and always had a good pastrami sandwich. But this time I was very disappointed. The Pastrami was not good. Not Good at all. The place was empty and to add insult to injury, they took the Onion Rings off the menu!  The service was good, but the place is not what it used to be. Very Sad!
Cannot justify the 30.00 I paid for this pasrami sandwich I've had pastrami from the supermarket that was much juicier and tastier " ripped off "
I had the best pastrami sandwich in my life. Thin sliced, lean and delicious.  They also have excellent matzo ball soup.

Gold, thank you for your hospitality brother, hope to see you soon.
Food was delicious.

One of the BEST B'DAY EXPERIENCE EVER. Sindi our server made the whole dining experience divine, special & memorable. She is sweet passionate full of positive attitude energy and driven. The food is scrumptious delicious the atmosphere is very homey. Keep it up
Sindi was AMAZING! Food arrived well Presented and on time. Staff ensured that we were satisfied! Definitely a must if you are looking to experience Albanian cuisine.

Great food. First time having Albanian food but everything tasted fresh. The bread was amazing and warm and soft on the inside and toasted on the outside. I would return for the bread and Ajvar sauce alone. I got the meat grilled platter and that was honestly more than enough. It was an assortment of meats that were very tasty but also super filling.

The restaurant itself felt like a world away from NY. The moment you step inside, from the decor to the waiters' uniforms, it felt like an attempt to recreate dining in what one would imagine is Albania.

The service was also pleasant. The waitress was patient with explaining the menu and suggesting a few times.

Would definitely recommend!

I have never had Albanian food before so I was very curious to check this place out.

The food was overall tasty without any real misses. To start, my friends and I tried a bunch of small bites including the tarator, roasted pepper, cheese pickled pepper, shop salad, and mantia. They give you amazing complimentary fresh bread which is served warm. I would come back for the bread alone. The tarator is a yogurt based dip that to me is like a cross between tzatziki and tahini sauce. It was light and refreshing and complemented a lot of the dishes we ordered well. The shop salad reminded me of a standard shepherd salad with chopped cucumber, tomatoes, and feta cheese. Mantia are essentially baked veal dumplings with a flaky outer wrapper which I really enjoyed. I got the mixed grill platter for my main which came with two types of sausages and meatballs. I enjoyed it but did not think it was that memorable, although I really liked the slaw that came with it.

Service was friendly and professional but a bit slow. The restaurant itself is warm and homey --- it reminded me of a comforting ski lodge. The reason why I am giving it four stars is that I think that everything is a bit too expensive given the relatively small portion sizes.

Overall, I think this place is worth trying if you are curious about Albanian food!

Lovely dinner here! The space looks small from the front but there's a good amount more seating as you walk further in.

We started with the sausage dip (5/5), which most mostly cheese, but absolutely lovely. It warms you up on a cold day, and has all the depth that I didn't even know I was hoping for. The bread is crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. Amazing way to start the meal.

We also tried the fli (3/5). The texture was interesting enough but it lacked flavor to me. In fact I had to dip it into my sausage dip.

Lastly, we shared the tava kosi (4/5). The lamb is SO tender, so yummy. The only reason I didn't give it 5/5 is I didn't love the flavor of rice it came with, which was a significant portion of the dish. My friend liked it though, so to each their own.

Great service and ambiance, would certainly come back!

This is our first time trying Albanian food and we really enjoyed it! The food was delicious and very unique. I notice their main protein consist of veal.

We ordered:
- sausage dip
- ajvar (tomato based dip)
- lecenik (spinach corn bread)
- Sarma (meat, rice, and vegetable wrapped in cabbage)
- skenderberg (stuffed smoked meat)

Everything was delicious but I wasn't a big fan of the skenderberg. It feel like I was eating an overly dried chicken bake from Costco. That's not to discredit the food quality of this place but more so of my personal preference of this dish. My favorite item was the Sarma, I love the warm taste of the stewed cabbage wrap.

The outdoor seating area is nice and they allow dogs. If you don't have a furry friend, definitely dine indoors as they decorated it to make you feel like you teleported to Eastern Europe. The ambiance is peaceful with dime lighting. The staffs are also super friendly and took their time explaining their menu and provided recommendations.

Highly recommend!

The good: Matia (veal dumplings) was as good as I'd remembered. The bread was still fresh out of the oven and fluffy as ever.

The bad: The "stuffed pepper" entry was one piece of de-seeded pepper on top of a bed of overcooked and under-seasoned rice... Was it supposed to be stuffed...? Who knows.

The ugly: The entries were way too small for the price. My Sausage Tava, while delicious, barely covered the bottom of the plate. Shrinkflation at its best. The cocktails were generic but brazenly overpriced. Wish I could say something nice about the service, but unfortunately it was slow and very chaotic.

Not sure if I'd return any time soon.

Awesome Albanian food!
I came here with two other people and we left stuffed! The complimentary bread in the beginning is so good, super soft and pillowy. We ordered two dips and enjoyed every bite of it! The mantias were also awesome.
The meat platter was nothing special, good to sample a little bit but the lamb dish was good! The lamb was super tender and the rice underneath was silky and great.
I'd come back to try more Albanian food!

This is a gem of a restaurant!

To be honest, I wasn't really sure what to expect before coming but the food and experience really blew me away.

It's a cozy and vibrant place with wonderful food - my husband and I had the Mantia (traditional baked veal dumpling) and the Mixed Grill Platter, and the food was absolutely divine.

I can't wait to come back here again!

We went here because we wanted to try Dua Lipas favorite restaurant and had never had Albanian food before!! It was quite good!!!

Honestly the free bread was one of the best things we ate - it was soooo fluffy and fresh!!!

Loved all the meats and the dip as well! Dua knew what she was doing by coming here!

Love love love this restaurant. We got there around 6pm with a reservation without knowing what to expect for Albanian food. Immediately the server greeted us with cheerfulness and good service. The ambience was also very intimate.

We ordered an Albanian coffee (full-immersion type of coffee) because we how unique it was online. Imagine Turkish coffee. Then we ordered the veal dumplings (Mantia). I was expecting Asian dumplings but it had a soufflé like soft and crispy skin and you dip it in yogurt.

We also ordered a lamb and rice dish. The rice was cooked in yogurt so it was very soft, almost like a cottage cheese spread and the lamb was very soft. Finally we ordered the sausage dish, and the sausages were very delicious and went well with the bread they served us.

The dessert (Très leches) was very different and was soft and flavorful.

Overall a very well rounded experience.

Exploring roots.

My first time here, entrance and decoration is very attentive. Wish backyard was open. We were kind a forced to sit outside, when we wanna go in, we kinda got faces. Listen, i seat where i feel comfortable!!!

Ordered soujouk dip in yogurt sauce, was tasty, ok! Soujuk pieces should be bigger.

Chopped salad was extremely fresh, cherry tomatoes, cucumbers and shredded feta.

Cannot miss the freshly baked bread!!! Yumm

Now it comes to cevap, i know the origin and know how it should taste and make it. Presentation was great. When it comes to taste, should be bigger sizes, fluffier.

Goulash, beef pieces was lost in the sauce. I wanna see bigger chunks. Taste was ok.

Albanian food - big yum! Got the pickled pepper to start which was sour tangy and delightful. Also got the bread to start which is huge and a must for all the extra sauce.

Entree was branzino and although it took a little longer than expected it was moist and flakey with a mild flavor accompanied by a tangy slaw! Loved it.

Service was a little slow but our server was very pleasant!

We stumbled across this Albanian gem in the Bronx while in Little Italy. The ambiance takes you back to a cozy restaurant in Albania. The decoration and woodsy style is very homesweethome vibe!

The service was very kind and helped us despite it being busy. They recommended the mixed grill platter and mante in yoghurt.

It was very good and fulfilling. There was warm bread too and it went fantastic with the mante. I was not a fan of the sausage in the mixed grill platter but everything else was on point!

I will come back here and try other things on the menu. I really like this place with authentic flavors and cozy setting

A+

I heard this was Dula Lipa's favorite restaurant, but don't quote me. Apparently the name means, whatever we have and it was all grea!

This was my first time trying Albanian food and it was great! We tried two dips (Ajvar and sausage dip), and the sausage dip was amazing. It came out with fresh bread, which was straight out of the oven! We then tried a variety of food (Lecenik, Sarma, Skenderbeg). The Lecenik was my favorite, as it was a very moist cornbread with cottage cheese on top, which complemented the bread very well. The ambiance was also really great - it felt like I was eating in an old friend's house and the servers was really nice/helpful.

Love me some Albanian food! Very much like back home, the mixed meat platter was so delicious and so was the pepper dip. I used to go to their location in the Bronx because it's the original and really but this one is just as good and also close to my house!! Service was really fast and they attend to me just the right amount. So clean and tidy with all the Albanian decoration!

RUN to Cka Ka Qellu!!!! Found this spot randomly and what a gem. The service is excellent. The food is phenomenal and the aesthetic is super traditional which makes the food even more tasty. Try all the dips for apps, the meatballs in yoghurt are PHENOMENAL and the bread they serve is delicious.

I come here all the time with my discerning Albanian wife. The food is great and reminds her of home. The place is so well decorated with a rustic charm. Service is friendly and they are willing to help those unfamiliar with the cuisine. Prices have increased. They should consider a discount for the regulars.

Strolling around Midtown on a warm Sunday after, I sought out Çka Ka Qëllu for an early dinner and got a table for 1 without a reservation at this cozy, wood + brick adorned spot.

Having never had Albanian cuisine, several choices on the menu looked interesting (Tava Kosi: lamb and rice baked in a yogurt + egg roux, Tasqebap: veal, tomato, onion with a thin mashed potato base, Tava Mantia: veal dumplings in a yogurt sauce) but I went for a bit of variety with the Mixed Grill Platter.

Fresh bread and ajavar (a zesty roasted red pepper dip) were complimentary: the ajavar was bold while the bread was revelatory: the best qualities of a fresh Italian loaf with the lightness of a pita.

That mixed grill platter had three meats with a tangy cabbage, carrot, and cucumber salad. The meats were qebapa (small, garlicky ground meat sausages), qofte (a ground meat patty), and suxhuk (a dry sausage). There wasn't much variation in the spices between the meats and the suxhuk was tough, though the qebapa were fantastic

Best and first Albania food I've tried!!
The dips with bread definitely keep you addicted.
Service was great and would totally come back!!! Apparently this is dua lipa's favorite restaurant in nyc! now I see why!

Fun dining experience with rustic east European setting. They have a variety of options on the menu, a bit limited for vegetarians or vegans. The bread as everyone recommended is fresh, fluffy and yummy. It goes well with the dips. The layered fli dish was great unlike other Albanian places which offer usually sweet fli. The beans stew was our favorite.

This place gets 5 stars based on the bread alone. Absolutely life changing, just smelling it gives you a high. Stumbled across this place walking to another restaurant but we literally stopped in our tracks when we saw a patio table eating the bread.

What we ordered:

Appetizers:
$8 Tarator: chilled yogurt blend with minced cucumber and garlic drizzled with parsley

Refreshingly creamy and a great compliment to the bread and meats. 8.7/10

$7 Ajavar: a piquant red roasted pepper spread

This was one of my favorite things we ordered. It's like a sweet, savory, and tart explosion in your mouth. It brings a brightness to the bread, and if you do a double whammy and dip the bread in the two dips it's truly a game changer. 10/10

Bread (complimentary): no words. 99999999999/10

Salad:

$17.50 Mediterranean Salad: cranberry, walnuts, apple, red beets, arugula, goat cheese, çka ka qellu dressing.

It's a solid salad. Is it worth $17.50? Maybe not. It's delicious however the portion is the size of a side salad. I would get it again thought because it just compliments the meat so nicely. 7/10

$15.50 Shop Salad: chopped cucumber, tomatoes, red pepper, and shredded feta cheese in olive oil & vinegar

This is a pretty standard cucumber tomato salad, I like the addition of a shaved feta as opposed to chunks because it was able to coat everything . Pretty solid, but nothing game changing. 7/10

Entrees:

$22.50 Tava Kosi: lamb and rice baked with a mixture of yogurt and eggs added to a roux.

This dish is so interesting. It's kind of like a cross between risotto and congee?? The rice is mixed into the yogurt and egg creating an extremely creamy concoction, so if you're not into that I would order this. I'm not much of a lamb person because of the gaminess and smell, however this looked so interesting and I had to try it. There is still the distinct smell of lamb, however it was cooked extremely well I couldn't taste the gaminess and it was fall of the bone tender. I wasn't a very big fan of the rice, but if you want something creamy, hearty and lamb-ey I would order it. Personally this was a 2/10 but to someone who enjoys those things it could be a 10/10.

$21 Sarma: cabbage leaves stuffed with ground veal, rice, vegetables, and seasoning

The dish was a lot more creamy than I expected given that these cabbage rolls were stewed in a tomato based sauce.  Its salty and a had a lot of umami, I think it would taste great with rice but that's just the Asian in me. I think I would've liked to see an element of brightness because I couldn't get through more than 2 bites without needing to break it up with something. Maybe I'm not accustomed to these flavors and dishes, but I just wish the dish had more components because there was just a cream sauce (sour cream?) on top. 4/10

$22 Mixed Grill Platter: combination of qebapa, qofte & sausage.

Highly recommend ordering this on your first time here! We wanted to try a variation of meats and this was the best way to do it. The Qebaba was my absolute favorite I came back 2 days later and ordered it standalone. The other meats were pretty good too though. The slaw that it comes with is so refreshing and a great add to break the heaviness up I just wish there was more. 9.7/10

Dessert:
$10.50 Baklava: I knew we had to try this because we overheard a guy say that he's tried a bunch of Baklava places and this one was the best. I'm not Baklava person, but this was pretty solid. Not too sweet, a generous amount of pistachios and a generous portion. I just wish it was more flakey and less soggy but I don't if that's just a Baklava thing. The check took a while to come though so we got bored and counted the layers. There's 43 of them. 5/10

Service:

I would come here with the intention of staying for at least an hour because they're a little short on waitstaff. I came once at 3pm on a Sunday and didn't have to wait for a table of 2. There were only 2 waitress from what I could see and it took a little long to get our food BUT they are the nicest ladies ever and I love them with my whole heart. I would say this lunch/dinner would last you 1.5-2 hours.

Overall Review: 9.5/10

TRY THIS BREAD IF THIS IS THE LAST THING YOU DO ON THIS EARTH!!!!! I would honestly just come back for the dips and bread, they are splendid. A perfect meal here for me would be the 2 dips (Tarator, Ajavar), lots of bread, Chopped and Mediterranean salads and the sausage platter. Have it all come out at the same time and make little concoctions with the ingredients. Bread base, 2 dips, raisin from Mediterranean salad, lil bit of sausage, some slaw and feta make for a life changing bite.

I speak about as much Albanian as I have green skin, but I'd happily hop on the next flight to Tirana if the food tastes as good as what this place serves. I can't pronounce the restaurant's name (it sounds like I'm trying to yodel and cough at the same time), but I do know what I liked from the menu:

- Ajavar: Tasty, mildly sweet roasted pepper spread with delicious, hot, freshly baked bread

- Shop Salad: Albania's version of shopska, the tomato and cucumber salad with local cheese you can find all over Eastern Europe. I'm partial to Bulgaria's, having had the real thing there, but I could be persuaded to bump Albania's up the list if CKQ's is representative

- Tava Kosi: Man, this dish needs to be sold in family portions, it's so dang good. Really, how can you go wrong with  lamb and rice baked with yogurt?

- Sarma: Only good things come wrapped in cabbage leaves

- Grilled Branzino: Simple but meaty, though I could've used more sauteed veggies

For dessert bites, we split the Albanian Trilece. I can't see the difference between this Albanian version and the OG, but it was tasty nonetheless.

The decor is gorgeous, woody, cozy, and all things Albanian hygge. It feels like being enveloped in the warm bosom of your Albanian grandma, and I'm pretty sure I'm not alone in being perfectly content to spend the rest of the night there.

This was the best find. The restaurant was tiny, but had the most stunning atmosphere that left us feeling like we were right in Albania. Portion sizes may not have looked the largest, but they were very hearty. We ordered tava dheut which was rich and full of flavor and mantia which came with six large veal dumplings in a warm sour cream sauce. If I had to choose a favorite, I'd say the tava dheut but both were fantastic. The meal came with some fresh bread which was perfect with the entrees. For two of us, this was the perfect amount of food. Overall, the food was great and the atmosphere was just incredible. I would definitely go back.

We recently went to Çka ka Qëllu, a rustic restaurant offering modern Albanian and Kosovan dishes. Once you step inside, you are transported to a warm, old-timey, authentic space. It is covered with wood and bricks, earthy tone that makes you think of grandparents' or great parents' home, maybe. There is a nice-size dining room at the front, and another dining room in the back. In between, there is a connecting space with a few more tables.

For appetizer, we ordered some dips with bread and a salad. We want to try Mediterranean Salad or the Village Salad, but somehow, the server simply put in order for the Shop Salad... It seems like you need to demand what salad you want, otherwise, it might be selected for you??? Anyways, the Shop Salad was a really nice.

For the dips, we got Tarator, Pickled Pepper, Sausage Dip, and Ajavar. The bread came piping hot! The inside was hallowed, made it easier to tear apart and dip into each dip. The creamy dips had more of a mild flavor, and the chilled ones had more distinctive, strong flavors. We enjoyed them all.

For the main, we ordered Mixed Grill Platter to share. It comes with a combination of qebapa, qofte & sausage. They all had similar flavors, but all so tasty! Packed with flavors, so delicious.

We ended our dinner with a dessert to share as well. We ordered Albanian Trilece. It was pretty darn good dessert!

We had a nice dinner hear, certainly interesting. The service was not so warm, but our water was always filled, and we were well taken care of. A nice change from any other cuisine you find in the city.

The space is nice and the servers were friendly but the food underwhelmed.

The sausage dip was runny and had 4-5 tiny tiny pieces of sausage in it which you couldn't taste.

The pickled peppers were way too salty

The village salad was good but on the smaller side.

The mantia dumplings were dry

The cornbread was a little mushy

The lamb and rice dish was good but I don't think there was actually any rice in it.

The mixed meat combo was all a little dry and over priced. When you think about it $55 can get you a pretty big dry aged steak somewhere else vs. a chicken breast, a mostly bone piece of lamb, some nondescript meats

I was expecting the food to be more homey and delicious but there was nothing that would make me want to come back.

OMG. This place was amazing!!! This was my first time eating Albanian food and wow it was delicious. Everything we had was an absolute winner. Started with sausage dip, which was basically a yummy cheesy sauce with pieces of sausage in it. It comes with delicious hot bread for you to dip/scoop with. Also had a kind of meat dumpling called mantie. Omg-to die for. Used the bread to scoop up the yummy sauce it came in. Then had a mixed meat grill and some kind of cubed meat with mashed potatoes in a rich reddish sauce. All of it fantastic. The service was great, everyone super nice and friendly. I can't wait to come back here.

5/5 Vibe - restaurant was a lil small but had 2 rooms with space for around 30 people. Had lots of cute Albanian decorations. Very cozy vibe.

5/5 food - we got a meat platter, tahini dip and multiple breads. The bread was super puffy and soft. So delicious! The meat was super rich - we got the liver which was gamey but still tasty.

5/5 service - the server was super nice and attentive despite how busy they were.

Omg what a stellar spot with excellent food, vibes, and service. I had never tried Albanian food before but my Albanian super spoke highly of this spot so I definitely had to try it. It absolutely measured up to the expectations.

First off, the decor is super cute and authentically Albanian with the traditional outfits on display. The service was exceptionally friendly and helpful with recommendations, and the staff is from Albania or at the least the Balkans.

We started with the pickled pepper with cheese which was excellent. The meal comes with complimentary bread that is BEYOND good. We also ordered the fli, which was basically a bunch of crepes stacked on each other - I liked it a lot, my mom thought it was just ok. Of every dish it was probably the weakest, but I still really liked it.

Next we had the mantia - this was my favorite dish of the entire meal. They're veal dumplings, but very different from say pierogies or pelmeni. They're crispier and flaky and just absolutely delicious. We also had the mixed grill platter and the meats were all delicious.

We finished with the trileçe which has a funny story - my mom and I are Mexican so I grew up on tres leches cake, and noticed "trileçe" sounds a lot like tres leches. Lo and behold, it was basically a tres leches cake covered in caramel. Apparently Albanians LOVE telenovelas, and saw it in a telenovela and started making it their own. It tasted similar, but slightly different, and was a delicious spin off. Love the culture blend from two very different parts of the world!

I'd 10/10 go back, and I'd absolutely bring friends in town here for a unique experience.

Giving 5 stars for the service -- our waitress was lovely and spent a lot of time walking us through the menu as we've never had Albanian food before.

The food is 4 stars -- overall tasty.

Albanian food is mostly meat, cheese and bread. The bread was amazing.

The diet cokes were $5 each which seemed steep.

Great place to check out Albanian cuisine. It was my first time having Albanian cuisine and I came here in a group of 6. We had the opportunity to try out many of the dishes in family style!
The restaurant has beautiful interior with arts and decorations.

I'm glad we came here for the meal and will return for more in the future!

First time trying Albanian fare here; it's a cute spot with a nice ambiance and friendly service.

We had the bread that came with some cheesy dip, as well as a variety of meats. The bread was delicious and it was fun to try all the different types of meat they had!

Honestly not sure if Albanian food fits my taste palate super well, but I definitely still enjoyed my experience here and am glad I tried this place!

This place is amazing, can't wait to go back! I'm a vegetarian and it was my first time having Albanian food. They were very accommodating. Everything we ate was so flavorful. The interior was beautiful and romantic.

Cka ka Qellu is a hidden gem in the heart of Manhattan. From the moment you step in, you're transported to Albania with its cozy and welcoming ambience. The interior was really cool, it was like old time Albania with their rich history explained in their wallpaper. The staffs were friendly and accommodating, especially the lady with glasses who gave us a warm welcome and a delightful dining experience.

Now let's talk about the food. We had the Fli, a traditional Albanian dish made of multiple layers of dough and meat. It was served with feta cheese and pickled green tomatoes, which added a nice tangy flavor. The portions were generous, and the prices were very reasonable considering the quality of the food. Everything we ordered was delicious and authentically Albanian. The Ajavar, a red roast pepper spread, was a perfect starter that paired so well with their freshly baked bread. We also had their chop salad, which was full of flavor and freshness. But the real stars of the show were the Qofte, Qebapa, and grilled chicken from their sampler menu. Each item was cooked to perfection and tasted amazing.

Overall, Cka ka Qellu is a must-visit for anyone looking for an authentic Albanian dining experience in Manhattan. The food, ambience, and service are all top-notch, and I can't wait to come back and try more of their menu. Highly recommended!

This place was so fun!! It's rare to come upon such a unique restaurant serving Albanian food with a rustic vibe. I had never tried this cuisine before, but I really enjoyed it and would come back with a group of friends.

My fav dish was the cornbread since it's was so soft and flavorful- not dense at all. The pepper dip was also delicious with their fresh warm pita! I got the meat sampler for my main and it was great to eat along with the appetizers or some rice.

- @nyconthetable

Mouth watering good! Loved every single app we ordered. So much flavor. The bread is to die for. So fresh and fluffy.  For our main we got the stuffed cabbage and mixed grill platter. Both amazing!
The ambiance and music is incredible too. Feels like you are in Albania!
Incredible food but make sure you come HUNGRY and with no lactose or gluten allergy!
Awesome food and service, everyone should go to the restaurant!!! The pita bread is soooooo delicious

This place is supposed to be Dua lipa's favorite restaurant on New York. The food was delicious but nothing very standout. I had the sausage dip and red pepper dip with pita bread. The main dishes was not that impressive and the fli was basically just pancakes that I never mastered. The environment was very nice though. Great for gathering

An Albanian friend brought a group of us here. The place is very clean and has a very nice classy interior design. They have both indoor and outdoor seating. The food was also of good quality. We had some grilled meat platters that had a large variety of different meats and they were all flavorful. They also serve you this homemade bread which is very soft and fluffy.

However, this place is not without its flaws. The portion size of everything was small. I guess it is be expected for an ethnic restaurant in Midtown. According to our Albanian friend, the menu was also missing many traditional items. They did not even have byrek here. If you are looking for an authentic home cooked style Albanian meal, it is probably better to go to the Bronx.

Beautiful and quaint little restaurant with authentic Balkan vibes.  Service was excellent and the servers explained the menu in detail. The food is great and as authentic as the motherland. Highly recommend the dumplings and meat dishes. Hearty and delish!

This was my first time trying Albanian food! I was happy to try out so many different things. My friends and I tried a collection of different foods. My favorite was probably the mantia which are like little pan fried dumplings. These were sooo good! We also had the Mixed Grill Platter which featured the sausages and other different meats. It was all seasoned really well. The table also came with complimentary bread that was so fluffy and delicious. We also got the sausage teva which was sausage in a cheesy sauce - great to dip in the bread. The waitress seemed like she didn't really want to be there haha but she warmed up when we asked how to pronounce the restaurant name and the meaning. The ambiance was amazing and cozy! We were in the back room and it felt like we were having dinner in a nice home. I'm glad I got to try this place!

The restaurant was cozy and charming. The food was amazing. It was our first time eating Albanian food. The service was very helpful in in helping us with picking popular/beat dishes. We will definitely go there again!

Gold was amazing!!
He is literally the best waiter and is such a jokester. He might make fun of you for "fangirling" about the restaurant (which I did) but he truly is the greatest. If you're lucky, you may have a an Albanian tour guide by the end of the night.
The food...I cannot say enough. I'm American (italian background) and was nervous cause I didn't know a lot about the food (granted I went with my Albanian best friend but she is also very Americanized). The food was absolutely DELICIOUS!
Faleminderit çka ka qëllu!

-Jax and Lindita

Best mediterranean food in New York.
Service 5*
Good 5*
Ambiance 5*
Pastry 6*
Will come back soon.

The food was great!  
Grisela was our server and she was very polite and welcoming.
Quiet and clean atmosphere with soft traditional Albanian music playing in the background.

Amazing time every time.  Great friendly service, great food, cute place. If vegetarian, get the stuffed peppers!

Also the bread is a must!

A traditional little restaurant that gives you an amazing taste of Albania ! It sits in a quiet area a little away from busy Midtown, making it easy to spot. I came here on a Friday night with my mom. We were seated right away and the servers were friendly. The decor was beautiful and had an old-fashioned vibe. They also had Albanian music playing inside (I believe they are from Kosovo).

For our appetizer, we tried the Tarator and Roasted Pepper. The Tarator was really tasty ! It had a taste similar to the tzatziki that I'm familiar with. It also had a nice and thick texture. The bread that came with it tasted very fresh and was served warm. I expected the roasted pepper to be a little bigger in size, but I still liked it.

For my main course, I ordered the Mixed Grill Platter. All of the meats were so delicious. They were seasoned very well and some were even a bit spicy ! Everything was cooked to perfection.

For dessert, we shared the Albanian Trilece. Similar to Tres Leches Cake, but thicker texture and distinctive flavors. The Trilece had the right amount of sweetness and I loved the caramel on top. I also tried the Albanian Coffee which was strong, but very good.

Overall the food was fairly priced, reasonable portions, and I would highly recommend coming here if you want to experience authentic Albanian cuisine !

i've been here twice and the food is great. the veal sliders are to die for, and the pita bread is amazing.

my friends loved the stuffed pepper but i thought it was just ok. we came at 7:30 and there was only 1 stuffed pepper left so we got a stuffed cabbage and it was also ok.

the second time i came the service just felt like it took a long time. we also sat outside and at one point we were like did they forget about us lol.

best avocado cucumber roll i've had anywhere. most fat, vibrant, sweet, perfectly ripened avocado slices i've ever seen in a sushi roll. i would share a picture but i inhaled all of my food so quickly the thought never even occurred to me. i eat a LOT of veggie rolls but i never once fathomed a roll could taste like that. 100000% going back specifically for more of that magic.

also had an age tofu (which was perfect, REALLY good sauce and nice portion) and a brown rice. we called them after closing but they offered to throw our order together no problem and we had it in 10 minutes. my dad got a yellowtail scallion roll he's been absolutely raving about, SUPER generous portion of fish that he claims 'will ruin every yellowtail roll i try from now on.' my sister had a philadelphia roll which she had no problem with (and looked excellent) but i think she was even more impressed with the veggie roll i got.

10/10 best use of your sushi money hands down. only wish we ordered early enough to try the fries, but i'm sure we will fairly soon !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Good sushi on the go. They work quickly and give you a good amount of food for your dollar. I liked their vegetarian options and the staff is friendly. Only reason I give 4 and not 5 stars is because I wish their ginger and wasabi tasted more fresh. Otherwise, great spot and will return again!

Ginza sushi is a solid spot if you want sushi or chinese food. The salmon bento box was also solid. The delivery came fast and hot. No complaints. Was it the best food I have had? No, but it did the job. 3 stars.

Quick in and out. Standard fare. Had veg rolls. Loved Avocado rolls.  Good experience ordering on phone.  Will recommend for veg rolls, for sure.  Spartan no frills decor suits just fine if you are looking for a take out.

Did sushi takeout and was very impressed. Really high quality fish, and the special rolls were not masked by overly strong or sweet sauces. The spicy scallop sushi was a star or the show. Just enough spice to know you ordered spicy, but not so much that you couldn't taste anything else. The vegetable tempura was a great portion for the price and the broccoli tempura was fun and unexpected. The other star was the teriyaki tofu. Light and fluffy soft tofu with a thin fried outside and a great sauce.

Takeout was fast and came with everything we needed to quickly dig in! 10/10 would recommend.

Menu items: S1. Miso Soup Spicy Tuna R5. Spicy Scallop Roll R7. Spicy Salmon Roll R15. Yellowtail Scallion Roll 14. Spicy Girl Roll 17. Volcano Roll

Sushi takeout is my Sunday night ritual, so I ordered from here to try a new place in my neighborhood. The order was ready really quickly, which was a plus. I ordered the spicy girl roll, a spicy salmon roll, and seaweed salad. When I opened up my order at home, I was disappointed since they gave me a salmon avocado roll instead of my spicy salmon roll. The spicy girl roll was good, but nothing over the top. Not sure if I will be back, but it was quick and affordable.

Very good, reliable, and bang for your buck sushi takeout joint! I've known about this place for a while but I didn't want to break up with Nobi down the street. I gave in one Sunday night and ordered the roll combo with yellowtail scallion, eel cucumber, and salmon avocado. I prefer Nobi's selection of roll combos since I haven't been a fan of yellowtail lately, but this roll changed my mind! The yellowtail was awesome with just enough scallion and plenty of delicious fish. The other rolls were great too as well as the miso soup! At $20 for a 3 roll combo meal and soup, they're on par with other value-based sushi in this part of the city. I'll definitely be adding them to my takeout rotation!

In this mostly residential neighborhood, takeout/delivery joints are a dime a dozen and destination restaurants are few and far between. Somehow, despite there being many, many places to order your standard sushi roll lunch and dinner specials, most of them fall short. The fish may be rubbery and of subpar quality and the rice overly sweet or overcooked. Ginza gets it right. The prices are standard, the food is fresh, and they've always gotten my order right, which is more than I can say at nearby sushi restaurants.

You'll find all the classics here, but I especially love the eel roll, yellowtail jalapeno, and salmon avocado. I'll order for pick up or delivery as there's no space to sit inside, but this place is so much better than the other spots in Murray Hill that I'll walk an extra few blocks to get the better sushi here.

Came here on a last minute decision and don't regret it. It's a small take out only sushi spot so I didn't expect too much but I was wrong. The portion size for these sushi was a good ratio between rice and fish and was filling. The lunch special was a good deal which was like $17 for 3 rolls and miso soup just like a lot of other sushi spots. The only reason I gave it a 4 star is because they only give you one small container for soy sauce even if you get like three rolls. Typically 2 would be fine.

Incredibly fresh and plentiful food! A must-try for anyone visiting or local. Let's dive in ...

Yellowtail Jalapeño Roll (5/5): Wow! That yellowtail tastes like it www caught today, while the jalapeño is kindly deveined and deseeded yet incredibly juicy and crunchy. This roll, as with the others, is well packed in a bountiful and yet organized way.

Spicy White Tuna Roll (5/5): Holy macaroni. This is the best spicy/crunchy roll of any sushi joint I've tried in the city. The tuna is ultra fresh and the spicy crunchy tempura part is actually really crunchy and not soggy like most places do; and it's flavorful nature was genuinely not expected and I'm the opposite of disappointed.

Alaska Mak (5/5): This large 5-piece roll really threw me off at first glance but checked all the boxes and then some. The cucumber crunches, the avocado is creamy, the salmon fresh as can be.

Salmon Skin Salad (4/5): There is an abundance of salmon skin in this salad. The rest is mostly lettuce and a sprinkle of shaved carrot and cucumber pieces.
